chap.title: Preface
chap.head: PREFACE.
chap.p: ANY one acquainted with the mo∫t popular dramas of the pre∫ent day will not accu∫e an author of much vanity, in thinking it no very difficult ta∫k to plea∫e the public in writing for the ∫tage.

Impre∫∫ed with this idea, when the Author of the following drama had an offer made him by a friend of the Deputy Manager of Covent Garden Theatre to pre∫ent any piece, and in∫ure its being, at lea∫t, read by him (for pieces are ∫ometimes refu∫ed without being read), he immediately ∫et about it; thinking he ∫hould be well repaid, if, for a few weeks trouble, he could put a few hundred pounds into his pocket; and that the lo∫s would not be very great if un∫ucce∫sful.

To produce a laughable piece, and give the mu∫ical compo∫er and ∫cene painter an opportunity of di∫playing their talents, was the object therefore in writing the following ∫cenes, rather than an attempt at writing a regular drama. Yet the Author, in ∫triving to plea∫e, did not ∫o far forget his duty as a morali∫t, as to ∫acrifice morality to mirth, and good ∫en∫e to ∫cenery; and while he attempted to amu∫e, he wi∫hed to expo∫e and lend his feeble aid to correct ∫ome of the follies of the age. He would have thought it a reflection upon the public to have exceeded the bounds of probability for effect, at lea∫t of ∫uch probability as the pre∫cription of the ∫tage allows: he would not have introduced an Otaheitean at the Lord Trea∫urer Burleigh's, nor have gone ∫o far as to "make his heroine blue."

He had flattered himself into the per∫ua∫ion, that the character of Veronica was new to the ∫tage; and, in able hands, would produce a very laughable effect: it was written purpo∫ely for Mrs. Mattocks; and, if the Author is any judge of the abilities of others, Mrs. Mattocks is the
only per∫on who could have performed it. In her line ∫he is unrivalled; and in her hands Veronica would have received a thou∫and touches, which the pen of an author could never ∫upply; and upon her powers the author would willingly have ri∫ked his ∫ucce∫s.

Now, whether the piece had no merit at all, or whether it had le∫s merit than the dramas which have lately been produced at Covent Garden Theatre, or whether the Author was too ob∫cure, and could not fill the boxes on its appearance, certain it is, that the piece, after a ∫hort time, was returned with a no; adding, that where a piece was not accepted, no remarks or ∫ugge∫tions were ever made.

The Author was now thrown upon the world. As money was his object, he did not apply to the other winter theatre, but pre∫ented it to the Manager of the Haymarket Theatre; thinking it po∫∫ible, if he approved it, that he might engage Mrs. Mattocks to perform the principle character, as he had formerly engaged Mr. Kemble
for a ∫imilar purpo∫e in one of his own pieces. But Mr. Colman thought "its repre∫entation would not ∫erve the intere∫ts of the Haymarket Theatre."

The Author had now only to reflect upon what had been before ∫ugge∫ted to him, that the piece was better adapted to the clo∫et than the ∫tage, as the character of Veronica could only have its full force with tho∫e who under∫tood botany. This was very true, but it was a circum∫tance that he was aware of even from the beginning. He flattered him∫elf, that as the ∫tudy of Botany was very fa∫hionable, and as almo∫t every body knew ∫omething of its outlines, the majority of an audience would under∫tand it, and the remainer would be plea∫ed with the comic ∫ound of the jargon, when delivered with humour, though unacquainted with its literal meaning. He had heard audiences ∫et into roars of laugher by Lingo's bad Latin, though perhaps four-fifths of the audience were unacquainted with the language. Moreover, French, Italian, German, and Scotch characters are generally
received with applau∫e, though their language is often perfectly unintelligible.

Unwilling, like a fond parent, that his child ∫hould remain in ob∫curity, the Author con∫igns it to the clo∫et, at the ∫ame time intreating the Reader to keep in mind, that it was written principally for acting, and for the ∫ingular manner of Mrs. Mattocks, to be ∫et off with the farther advantages of mu∫ic, and the mo∫t beautiful ∫cenery that can be imagined. Had it appeared on the ∫tage, many parts would have been con∫iderably curtailed, as too long for effect in repre∫entation, but which the Author hopes will, neverthele∫s, prove entertaining in the clo∫et, if not ab∫olutely e∫∫ential to his de∫ign: he wi∫hed, as much as po∫∫ible, to realize to his Reader the ∫pot where he has laid his ∫cene, that tho∫e who have ∫een it may recall the original to their minds, and to give the be∫t idea of it in his power to tho∫e who have not.

It only remains to ∫ay a few words upon the objects of the ridicule. The Author a∫∫ures him∫elf
he is not ∫ingular in thinking the ∫tudy of Botany not altogether a proper amu∫ement for the more poli∫hed ∫ex; and the fal∫e ta∫te of a licentious age, which is gaining ground, and corrupting the ∫oft and elegant manners of the otherwi∫e lovelie∫t part of the creation, requires every di∫couragement which can be given.
SHOULD this Drama fall into any one's hands who is neither acquainted with the Lakes, nor a picture∫que Traveller, nor a Botani∫t, it may be proper to recommend to his peru∫al, by way of

stanza.line: WHERE CUMBRIA's mountains in the north ari∫e,
Where cloud-capp'd SKIDDAW ∫eeks the azure ∫skies,
Nature hath ∫hower'd from forth her lavi∫h hand
Her choice∫t beauties o'er the favour'd land.
There verdant hills the fertile vales divide,
And at their ba∫e pellucid rivers glide;
Or the broad lake, out∫tretch'd in wide expan∫e,
Di∫covers to the trav'ler's wond'ring glance
Enchanting ∫cenes, which captivate the ∫oul,
And make therein delightful vi∫ions roll.
There bleak crags their barren bo∫oms bare,
Stupendous cataracts hideous cha∫ms wear,
From rock to rock they force their headlong way,
Stun with their noi∫e, and fill the air with ∫pray;
The hanging cliff its dreadful ∫afety yields,
Where Jove's produ bird its annual eyrie builds.
Thither, attracted from their peaceful home,
The Poet and the Painter love to roam,
Feed fancy full, 'till fraught with fire divine,
Their beauties on the page and canva∫ ∫hine;
There CUMBERLAND enrich'd his moral mu∫e,
And FARRINGTON produc'd his matchle∫s Views.
stanza.note: Of all the views of the Lakes Mr. Farrington's are perhaps the be∫t, and the mo∫t faithful repre∫entations; yet he has certainly taken ∫ome liberties. Had this Prologue been written after the opening of an Exhibition for the pre∫ent year, Mr. W. Turner's name would have been mentioned as an arti∫t, who∫e Views of the Lakes do honour to him∫elf and the ∫cenes they repre∫ent.
stanza.line: There, too, the botani∫t, with prying eyes;
Culls the fair flowers in all their thou∫and dyes;
The teeming waters yield the ∫caly race,
And the keen ∫port∫man joins the noi∫y cha∫e;
Health, ro∫y godde∫s, there unharm'd re∫ides,
And Liberty, the mountain nymph, pre∫ides.
Each ∫ea∫on there delighted myriads throng
To pa∫s their time the∫e charming ∫cenes among:
For plea∫ure, knowledge, many thither hie,
For fa∫hion ∫ome, and ∫ome -- they know not why.
And the∫e ∫ame vi∫itors, e'en one and all,
The Natives by the name of LAKERS call.
There has our Author fix'd his Drama's Scene,
Such are his Characters, if right I ween:
A motley groupe, of various ta∫tes, no doubt,
And each pur∫uing what his ta∫te points out;
But how together brought, and what befell
The∫e Lakers there, the Piece it∫elf mu∫t tell.
Thus much the Prologue for the Drama ∫ays, --
And now the Author for your patience prays;
Hopes that you'll all your be∫t of humours wear,
And to exert your candour will prepare;
For I am bid to ∫ay in his behalf,
He humbly hopes that he ∫hall make you laugh,
And, as he ∫hows, ∫o likewi∫e let him reap,
And, if he makes you laugh, give not him cause to weep.

p.i: A Room at the Queen's Head.

chap.p: Sir Charles (without).SPEEDWELL, ∫ee the hor∫es taken care of; and then inquire at the Po∫t-office whether there are any letters. (Shown in by Landlord.)
Landlord. You are welcome to Ke∫wick again, Sir Charles.

Sir Charles. Thank you, Landlord. -- Again and again, I hope. While Ke∫wick di∫plays its wonders, and health and amu∫ement are to be acquired in ∫urveying them, I want nothing but opportunity to bring me here oftener. Have you had much company this ∫ea∫on? Many LAKERS?
Landlord. Sights of 'em, Sir. The hou∫e is now as full as it can hold; and, if any more ∫hould come in, I don't know what we ∫hall do.
Sir Charles. Have you had many people of note?
Landlord. No, Sir. Lord Par∫imony was here la∫t week: but then you know, Sir, he travels with only a pair of hor∫es, and orders only a pint of wine.

Sir Charles. A good hint, Landlord. Why you inn-keepers in the north had once the character of being civil and contented in your manners, and moderate in your charges. Now, if you retain your civility, you are certain to lo∫e your moderation.
Landlord. Why, Sir, travellers u∫ed to wonder at the rea∫onablene∫s of our charges, and we are not ∫o dull as not to take a hint when it is given us.
Sir Charles. Yes, we mu∫t thank our∫elves for that.
Landlord. Sir Incurious Hurry has been here too.

Sir Charles. He never fails. Sir Incurious is ∫o pa∫∫ionately fond of travelling, and the Lakes, that he drives po∫t through every country every year, with the carriage windows up, and never gets out but to eat, drink, and ∫leep.-- Who el∫e? But I mu∫t call at Crothwaite's and ∫ee the li∫t.
Landlord. A gentleman was here la∫t week, who inquired after Sir Charles Portin∫cale. He is a Cambridge gentleman, Sir, and was here the la∫t time you was.
Sir Charles. With his gun and his rod?
Landlord. Never a day but he was out either ∫hooting or fi∫hing.
Sir Charles. Ay, Tom Angle. The keene∫t ∫port∫man that ever lived. He knows the time of every fly, from the green-drake to the palmer-fly.
Enter Speedwell, with a Letter.
Speed. Only this letter, Sir.
Sir Charles. Very well. Landlord, I had an early dinner, ∫o ∫hall want ∫ome ∫upper.-- Speedwell, where are the ∫addle-bags? I want my pocket-book.
Landlord. They were carried into the bar, Sir.
[Exit, with Speedwell.

p.i: Sir Charles. (Opens the letter, and reads)

chap.p: "Dear Charles,

"Since we parted at Lanca∫ter, I have gained ∫ome intelligence of your pair partner, which I judge advi∫eable to communicate to you. The aunt, whom Lydia mentioned, is Mi∫s Beccabunga Veronica, of Diandria Hall, a great botani∫t and picture∫que traveller, who, with her nephew Bob Kiddy, are taking the tour of the Lakes. Mi∫s Beccabunga has a large fortune, part of which is in her own di∫po∫al; the re∫t goes to Lydia, at her death. She is, I under∫tand, very impatient for a hu∫band --"
Yes, she has been studying the ∫y∫tem of plants, till ∫he now wi∫hes to know the ∫y∫tem of man.

--"and pre∫uming upon Lydia's dependance upon her, during her life, in∫i∫ts upon having the fir∫t attack upon, and refu∫al of, every per∫on who comes in their
way. A title is her ambition. You mu∫t therefore fortify your heart and per∫on again∫t her attacks. No doubt you will ∫ee, or hear of, them again, in the cour∫e of your tour: they intend being at Ke∫wick on the twentieth. Adieu. I wi∫h you succe∫s. Yours, ∫incerely, though in ha∫te, H. FRIENDLY."

The twentieth! That is, to-day. Here then a new campaign opens upon me. I have to take one heart, whil∫t I re∫i∫t the attacks of another. The ∫ervice of Bellona mu∫t, for a ∫hort time, give way to that of a milder diety.
chap.head: AIR.

line.i: Though the Godde∫s of War is the mi∫tre∫s I ∫erve,
Yet Beauty has ∫urely a claim;
From the dictates of Honour my heart will not ∫werve,
Nor reject the bright triumph of Fame:
But vain is all conque∫t, the triumph how vain,
A trifle not worth our regard,
Unle∫s the dear ble∫∫ing of peace to maintain,
With Beauty the precious reward.

chap.p: Enter Speedwell, with Saddle-bags.

Sir Charles. Put down the ∫addle-bags, and come hither. I took you into my ∫ervice, Speedwell, while you were yet very young and uninformed. Your parents, though they were poor, were hone∫t, and by their birth de∫erved better than they received from the hands of fortune. Though ∫ervants, they have been faithful friends to our family; and I promi∫ed them to take care of you. That promi∫e, I think, I have fulfilled: I have treated you more upon the footing of a friend than a ∫ervant; have taught you my∫elf, as far as circum∫tances would permit, and had you in∫tructed by others, both in your duty as a man, and in what other knowledge might be u∫eful to you in pa∫∫ing away your lei∫ure hours in innocent amu∫ement.
Speed. You have never, I hop, Sir, found me wanting in gratitude for your kindne∫s?

Sir Charles. By no means. I mention not the∫e things to remind you of any obligation you may be under to me, but of the duty you owe your∫elf in enjoying
the∫e advantages. You have ∫erved me faithfully, and I will now put you in a way to better your pro∫pects for life.
Speed. I de∫ire no other pro∫pect, Sir, than that of ∫erving Sir Charles Portin∫cale till my death.

Sir Charles. You will ∫erve me al∫o in ∫erving your∫elf. -- You know the whole circum∫tance of my meeting with a lady at the ball of Lanca∫ter. She has my affections, and, if I can gain hers, I mean to offer her my hand. But there is an impediment in the way of our union. She had an aunt, upon whom ∫he is dependent during her life, and who claims to her∫elf the privilege of having the fir∫t refu∫al of every man they get acquainted with. I have rea∫on to think they will be Ke∫wick this day, or ∫oon. And, to ∫creen my∫elf from the attacks of the aunt, whil∫t I may have an opportunity of paying my addre∫∫es to my Lydia, I ∫hall change characters with you. You ∫hall introduce your∫elf as Sir Charles Portin∫cale; and if, under that character, you ∫hould like the aunt, and gain her con∫ent, marry her. I will undertake to accommodate matters after: if not, it, at any rate, gives me an opportunity of furthering my love with Lydia unmole∫ted. I am not per∫onally known to her aunt, as ∫he left the a∫∫embly indi∫po∫ed early in the evening. You have talents to play the part a∫∫igned to you; you know all my circum∫tances, and have only to order me to attend con∫tantly upon you, and whil∫t, in ∫urveying the pro∫pects, you engage the aunt, I ∫hall find opportunities with my Lydia. I will ∫ettle the affair with our landlord. Therefore put on your character immediately. Get out my dre∫∫ed coat from the ∫addle-bags. A red coat has attractions in it∫elf.
Speed. As far as it concerns you, Sir, I will execute the plot to the be∫t of my ability. But no mercenary motives ∫hall induce me to marry an unde∫erving woman, or one I cannot love.
Sir Charles. That is a ∫entiment, Speedwell, which would do honour to the heart of a peer.
[Speedwell undoes the ∫addle-bags, takes out a coloured frock with ∫urpri∫e, and ∫everal brown-paper parcels, with ∫till greater.]

Speed. If the lady, Sir, is like the turkey-cock, and flies only at the red coat, and not at the wearer, I fear
there will be no attack; for the coat has changed its colour, and, what's more, it has changed its fa∫hion.
Sir Charles. How?

Speed. (Undoing one of the parcels.) Pieces of linen! I have it, Sir. If you remember, Sir, the landlady at Penrith bought a pair of ∫addle-bags into your room, and de∫ired you to let a traveller be there, as the hou∫e was full; "his name was Billy Sample, from Manche∫ter, and he was a virry nice young man." Now I take it, Sir, that either I through mi∫take, or he through de∫ign or mi∫take, has changed the ∫addle-bags, and that the∫e are the bagman's patterns.
Sir Charles. How is this? the bags were padlocked.

Speed. Yes, Sir, but ours was a lock that opens with a ∫pring without a key, and this is the ∫ame. I am confident that I packed them up right, for when you ∫aid that the gig was to be left behind to be repaired, and then follow us, I changed ∫ome things from the ∫eat to the bags.

Sir Charles. How heedle∫s! However, inquire for him here, and at the other hou∫e. If he is not here, you mu∫t go back to Penrith, and ∫ee after them. He may be gone another way. But, when he finds his mi∫take, he will be as much di∫appointed as I am, and perhaps come after us.
Speed. He's mo∫t likely coming this way, Sir; for he offered fir∫t you, and then me, a ∫ide in his gig.

Sir Charles. Well, go and inquire, and keep a lookout for the ladies. (Exit Speedwell.) Happy man! to have another opportunity of conver∫ing with my Lydia, to hear her charming voice, and again be fa∫cinated by her bewitching ∫mile!
chap.head: AIR.

line.i: It was not her form, nor her features ∫o fair,
Her eloquent eyes, nor her fine flowing hair,
Nor her wit, her good ∫en∫e, nor her grace;
All the∫e had their part,
But what captur'd my heart,
Was the ∫mile that beam'd ∫weet on her face.
The form it may fade, and the features may change;
Oft wit, by its malice, true love will e∫trange,
And the heart from its victim will ∫purn;
But the flame I de∫ire
Burns like Ve∫ta's pure fire,
For the ∫mile of good-temper's eterne.

chap.head: Enter Speedwell.
chap.p: Speed. Sir, I have found them both, the bagman, who has got your coat, and the lady, who has got your heart.
Sir Charles. What, my Lydia?
Speed. And her aunt, Sir. All three coming in the bagman's gig. I ∫uppo∫e they accepted the ∫ide you refu∫ed.
Sir Charles. Impo∫∫ible!
Speed. It's true, as I live, Sir; and, what is more, he has got your coat on; and, ∫till more than that, your dre∫∫ed hat out of the hat-box. Here they come, Sir.
Sir Charles. A∫toni∫hing! let us ∫tand a∫ide and ob∫erve them. Take up the cloathes however.
chap.head: Enter Vernonica, Lydia, and Sample in Regimentals, shown in by Landlord, bearing Scotch Plaid, Boxes, etc.
chap.p: Landlord. The party in the be∫t room are going away immediately, and you ∫hall have that, Madam. Here is an account of the mu∫eums. (Gives papers.)

Ver. How ∫upremely fortunate! A guide and botani∫t, "well acquainted with the rare indigenous plants of the mountains, rocks, and lakes." I beg you'll de∫ire the guide and botani∫t to repair hither directly.
Sir Charles. (A∫ide to Speed.) That is my cue; do you wait upon the officer. [They retire.]

Ver. Pray ∫ee all the things taken out, and bring my drawing-box in∫tantaneou∫ly. I would not lo∫e my ∫ketches and the manu∫cript of my tour for the world. I am ∫ure, Sir, we are under an infinitude of obligations to you for this favour. If it had not been for your kindne∫s when the Sociable broke down, I don't know what we could po∫∫ibly have done.
Sample. You are very welcome, Mi∫s. But bringing your luggage and all was rather too much. The hor∫e is knocked up.

Ver. O dear, don't give your∫elf any unea∫ine∫s on his account. If he ∫hould die, I'll write a monody, or an
epitaph, or an elegy upon him, and that will immortalize him.
Sample. But it won't buy me another hor∫e.
Ver. But it will. Publi∫h it on a wire-wove, hot-pre∫∫ed, cream-coloured paper, with the fac-∫imiles on the other ∫ide; I'll do ∫ome de∫igns for it, and it will ∫ell for a guinea.
Sample. But a guinea won't buy me a hor∫e.
Ver. If it is a hundred, you ∫hall have it. But pray, may I know to whom I am indebted for this kindne∫s?
Sample. I always forget my name. It's lucky it's with-in∫ide my hat.(A∫ide, taking off his hat, and looking into it.) Sir Charles Port-in-∫cale, Mi∫s.

Ver. How fortunate! The elegant and accompli∫hed Sir Charles Portin∫cale, and a botani∫t too. I mu∫t have him. (A∫ide.) To have received this favour from Sir Charles Portin∫cale, of who∫e merits the world ∫o loudly ∫peaks, adds weight to the obligation, and makes it ine∫timable.
Sample. And pray, Mi∫s, what's your name?
Ver. You do me infinite honour, Sir Charles; my name is Beccabunga Veronica, of Diandria Hall; my hybernaculum is in Gro∫venor Square. --Lydia--
Sample. Well, Mi∫s Beccy Bungay--
Ver. Why, Lydia, why don't you acknowledge Sir Charles? You know you danced with him at Lanca∫ter.
Lydia. I had the honour of dancing with Sir Charles Portin∫cale at Lanca∫ter. But it was not for me to ∫peak fir∫t. What can this mean? (A∫ide.)
Ver. Sir Charles, you don't ∫eem to recollect your partner?
Sample. My partner!
Ver. Don't you remember at Lanca∫ter a∫∫ize-ball? I unfortunately danced the two fir∫t dances in a different ∫et, and was then taken ∫o ill as to be obliged to go home.
Sample. I wasn't at -- Plague on't! I forget who I am. (A∫ide) O ay; we danced Morgan Ratler.
chap.head: Enter Speedwell.
chap.p: Speed. I have ∫een the hor∫es taken care of, Sir, ordered your bed, and a bird and bottle for ∫upper.
Sample. Taken care of!-- bird and bottle!
Speed. I got here ju∫t half an hour before you, Sir.
Ver. Is this your ∫ervant, Sir Charles?
Speed. I have the honour, Madam, to ∫erve Sir Charles Portin∫cale.
Ver. You never told us of him, Sir Charles. I did not know you had a ∫ervant with you.
Sample. Nor I neither. (A∫side.)
Ver. It was very unlucky he was gone on when our voiture broke down, or he might have a∫∫i∫ted us in our pericula.
Sample. That's the name of your carriage, is it? You called it a Sociable ju∫t now. He might have brought one of you behind him.
Ver. Ride double! how unpicture∫que! If you have no objection, Sir Charles, we will join parties, and add ∫omething to your roa∫t fowl and bottle.
Sample. Roa∫t fowl and bottle! 'twould eat up all my profits. I ∫hall only have a bit of cold meat and ∫ix-pen'orth of brandy and water.
chap.head: Enter Sir Charles, in Sample's Cloathes.
chap.p: Sir Charles. Oh! the ladies who want me are in this room. (Without.) Does your Lady∫hip want me? I am the guide and botani∫t, Ma'am. (Significantly to Lydia.) Sir Charles Portin∫cale. I am the guide and botani∫t. (To Sample.)
Lydia. What, my partner at Lanca∫ter! Was he an impo∫ter then, or is he now? My heart tells me he is true, and I am willing to be guided by him.

Sample. Why, what can this mean? This mu∫t be Sir Charles, and in my cloathes. Well, if he won't know me, I'm ∫ure I don't wi∫h to know him; and, if he likes my cloathes better than his own, he ∫hall have 'em. I ∫hall ∫ooner make a fortune by a red coat, than by riding for Dimity and Co. (A∫ide.)

Ver. (Looking through gla∫∫es.) A va∫tly picture∫que figure, I declare! Extremely intere∫ting! What, you are the Ciceroni of Derwent-water? I ∫ee, Mr. Botani∫t, that you have complete collections of the plants of the country, ready packed to ∫end off. I de∫ire I may have a collection.
Sir Charles. If you Lady∫hip will give me your direction, you may depend upon their being ∫ent.
Ver. I mu∫t have them now. I de∫ire you'll get them directly.
Sir Charles. I fear I have not a complete collection by me.
Speed. (A∫ide.) Suppo∫e, Sir, you give her one of the bagman's parcels. She will not undo it before ∫he goes away from hence.
Sir Charles. I believe here is a collection I was ju∫t going to direct and ∫end off; but your Lady∫hip ∫hall have them.
Ver. Very obliging, indeed! What do they come to? What is the appretiation of them?
Sir Charles. A guinea, if you plea∫e, Madam.
Ver. Sir Charles, may I beg the favour of you to pay for them? Pray untie and let me in∫pect them.

Sir Charles. I beg they may not be undone before you get home, as it would expo∫e them to the air, and they might ∫uffer from it. Your Lady∫hip ∫hall ∫ee another parcel undone before you leave Ke∫wick.
Ver. Va∫tly well. Sir Charles, I beg the favour of a guinea?
Sample. I think, Mi∫s Becky, you had better expo∫e them. Why, you wouldn't give a guinea for a parcel of patterns?
Ver. Patterns! We call them ∫pecimens, Sir Charles.

Sample. Spicemen! Why ∫he doesn't think ∫he's buying a bale of gingerbread nuts. But I forget my∫elf. (A∫ide-- gives a guinea.) There, Sir, if they are not right, you give the guinea back again.-- It's very hard to give a guinea for my own goods, when they're not worth it, and not have 'em neither. If he doesn't pay me, I'll melt the gold lace off his coat and pay my∫elf. (A∫ide.)
Ver. I dare ∫ay they are all right. There are the lichens among∫t them, I hope?
Sample. Yes, ∫he's a liking for my guinea, I ∫ee. (A∫ide.)
Ver. Sir Charles, I ∫hall re∫t your debtor.
Sample. I hope not, Mi∫s.
Ver. I ∫hall beg, Mr. Botani∫t, to depo∫it my bu∫t and leg in your mu∫eum.
Sir Charles. Your Lady∫hip will do me infinite honour, even by ∫etting your foot in it.
Ver. Very prettily turned indeed.
Sample. Your leg, Mi∫s?

Ver. I am a bit of ∫culptor, and model in pla∫ter. I had fini∫hed one exqui∫ite bu∫t of my∫elf, ∫o cla∫∫ifcal, but I ∫poiled it in the baking. I have, however, ∫ucceeded tolerably well in my ∫econd attempt: but every body ∫ays my leg is the fine∫t they ever ∫aw, and it is now in the po∫∫e∫∫ion of every lover of virtu.
Sample. Well, Mi∫s Becky, I don't ∫ee much virtue in it, but I ∫hould like to ∫ee your legs; though I always thought ladies wi∫hed to hide 'em.

Ver. O dear, no! quite the contrary. I played a breeches-part at my theatricals purpo∫sely to ∫how my leg. I have ju∫t perfected a highly fini∫hed colo∫∫al ∫tateue of the Poli∫h dwarf in marble: I hewed it even from the block; and pre∫ented it to Lord Ta∫tele∫s, -and he has entirely ∫poiled it by putting bra∫s buckles, ∫word-hilt, and lace to the hat.
Sample. Why, 'twould ha'been hand∫omer if he'd gone to the expen∫e of ∫ilver.
Ver. We had better take a ∫hort perambulation before ∫upper.
Sir Charles. If you Lady∫hip plea∫es. An evening pro∫pect from Crow Park is reckoned particularly fine. And, if we go now, we ∫hall have the advantage of both the ∫un∫et and the ri∫ing moon.
Lydia. I beg, Madam, that we may go. I am cramped with fitting in the carriage, and make no doubt I ∫hall be better for the walk.

Ver. I would not lo∫e it for the world. What a fine de∫cription it will make for my tour. Sir Charles, what ∫ay you to a turn? You mu∫t take infinite plea∫ure in viewing the delightful and impre∫∫ive ∫cenes of this country, as you travel through it?

Sample. Why, Mi∫s, I u∫ed to ∫tare about me a good deal, when I fir∫t came, from the novelty of the thing. But, now I'm u∫ed to it, I think no more of 'em than nothing at all: I think of nothing but taking orders.
Ver. Ble∫s me, Sir Charles, I hope you don't think of leaving the army?
Sample. Leaving the army, Mi∫s!-- O ay--O no, Mi∫s.
Ver. You talked of going into the church.
Sample. The church!
Ver. You ∫aid you thought of nothing but taking orders.
Sample. O yes, Mi∫s, for our hou∫e. I get my living by it.
Ver. What, you've a family living?
Sample. I've no family, Mi∫s, but I don't care how ∫oon I have one.
Ver. O Sir Charles, you might leave that for your ∫econd ∫on-- particularly if your wife has a fortune.
Sample. I ∫hould not mind at all giving up my travelling bu∫ine∫s to my ∫on.
Ver. By no means, Sir Charles; I am a traveller my∫elf.
Sample. Are you, Mi∫s? What hou∫e do you travel for? Where are you patterns?
Ver. You will call them patterns, Sir Charles-- Specimens.
Sample. Spicemen! What, you travel for one of the great We∫t India merchants?
Ver. I hope to travel for all the world.
Sample. That's too much to hope, Mi∫s.
Ver. Not at all, I hope-- I mean to make a thou∫and pounds by my tour.
Sample. That's doing bu∫ine∫s well. But I don't wonder at it. I am ∫ure I could not refu∫e giving an order to ∫uch a nice creature. But I never heard of a woman traveller before.
Ver. Ble∫s me, Sir Charles, why they're quite common.
Sample. Well, if I was married, my wife ∫hould go one way and I another.
Ver. That is the modern fa∫hion to be ∫ure: but I cannot ∫ay I ∫hould like it.
Sample. Why, then we'd go together. I'd travel in the Manche∫ter line, and you in the We∫t India.
Ver. Why, that would be travelling the ∫ame way with a witne∫s.
Sample. Yes, yes, we ∫hould witne∫s each other's dealings.

Ver. A va∫tly ∫ingular man is this Sir Charles. Not very poli∫hed, nor very accompli∫hed. However, I mu∫t have him. His fortune and title are both good, and I ∫hall have the merit of improving him. (A∫ide.) Pray, Sir Charles, could you be contented to be a monogymia all your life?
chap.note: Monogymia, in botantic language, ∫ignifies po∫∫e∫∫ing one female.
chap.p: Sample. Be contended to bemoan my guinea here all my life! (Half a∫ide.) No, Mi∫s, I can't ∫ay I ∫hould.
Ver. O fie, Sir Charles! I know you captains are great rovers, but you ∫hould not own it. Well them, a digynia?
Sample. Die for my guinea here! (Half a∫ide.) No, not that neither, Mi∫s.
Ver. Horrid! What mu∫t you be-- a trigynia, or a tetragynia, or a pentagynia?
Sample. Yes, (Half a∫ide.) I've ∫pent my guinea here.
Ver. An ab∫olute Turk! I wonder you ∫hould ∫ay ∫o on my account. Why, you would not keep a ∫eraglio?
Sample. If it is not on your account, I don't know on who∫e it is. -- I don't under∫tand three words ∫he ∫ays. I never heard ∫uch lingo before. (A∫ide.) Well, Mi∫s, ∫uppo∫e we walk.
Ver. If you plea∫e, Sir Charles, I ∫hall beg the favour of your arm. Here, Mr. -- what is your name?
Speed. Speedwell, at your ∫ervice, Madam.

Ver. A va∫tly good name, indeed. -- Pray take my gla∫∫es and my drawing-book, and my fi∫hing-∫tool. Come, Lydia; why, you look as ∫trange -- Come, I wi∫h you'd ∫tudy botany. Do, Mr. Botani∫t, in∫truct her a little; ∫how her a cryptogamy or two.
Sample. What game's that, Mi∫s?
Sir Charles. I'll ∫how her one your Lady∫hip never ∫aw.
Ver. Oh no, I prote∫t again∫t it. I mu∫t have the fir∫t ∫ight of it my∫elf. Is it an ophioglo∫∫um, a jungermania, a lycoperdon, or a polypodium?
Sir Charles. I think it will prove one of the filices (vice felices
Ver. I mu∫t ∫ee it. Come, let us be walking-- Where is my para∫ol?
Sir Charles. You will ∫carce have any u∫e for it, Madam.
Ver. O yes, it will give me a more picture∫que effect.
Lydia (as they go out). Sir Charles, this mu∫t be explained.
Sir Charles. Be a∫∫ured it ∫hall, and to your ∫atisfaction.

chap.title: THE LAKERS, ACT 1 SCENE II
chap.head: SCENE II

head.i: A Beggar and his Dog-- The Dog ∫itting upon his hind Legs.

chap.head: SONG.
chap.p: Beggar.

line.i: Oppre∫s'd with grief, depriv'd of ∫igt,
My cheerful day is turn'd to night,
For all is dark to me;
No hou∫e to ∫helter o'er my head,
And forc'd to beg my daily bread:
Pray be∫tow your charity.
Your battles have I fought abroad,
Whil∫t you were at your fe∫tive board,
And all was mirth and glee;
Then, cold and hunger'd, have I lain
Upon the damp and de∫ert plain:
Pray be∫tow your charity.
A trifle now is all I crave
To re∫cue from the gaping grave
My faithful dog and me.
O give-- and for the friendly boon,
Ju∫t Heav'n ∫hall ∫hower its mercies down:
Pray be∫tow your charity.

chap.p: At the end of the fir∫t ver∫e Veronica enters, leaning on Sample's arm; Lydia talking with Sir Charles; and Speedwell following. Veronica li∫tens attentively, gives her para∫ol to Sample to hold, and ∫tands in an attitude. After the ∫econd ver∫e, ∫he exclaims, "How intere∫ting!" After the third, "And the little dog too! Dear creature! What a powerful appeal to a too ∫u∫ceptible heart! How happy ∫hould I be to do any thing for the amelioration of his condition! --Sir Charles, have you got any halfpence?"
Sample. What, more money! She'll brozier me. (A∫ide.) No, Mi∫s, I have not.
Ver. Then a ∫ixpence?
Sample. Not a ∫ixpence, Mi∫s.
Ver. Then a ∫hilling, I beg. I ∫aw one when you took our your pur∫e ju∫t now.
Sample. I don't like her tricks upon travellers. But as I'm a great man, and her lover, I ∫uppo∫e ∫he mu∫t have it. (A∫ide.) There, Mi∫s, that makes one pound two.
Ver. Don't di∫turb the∫e amiable feelings of refined ∫en∫ibility. (Drops the ∫hilling into the beggar's hat-- pau∫es -- takes out her handkerchief, and puts it to her eyes.)
Beggar. Heaven ble∫s you!
Sample. You need not cry, Mi∫s; the lo∫s is mine, and not yours.
Ver. Lead me away. The∫e quick vibrations of the fine fibres of my heart are too much for ∫o ∫lender a frame.
Sample. Well, but you ∫ee I don't cry.
Ver. Stop, Sir Charles. I ∫hall lo∫e the force of it, if I don't write it down while the impre∫∫ion is warm. (Takes out her book, and writes.)
chap.head: SONG.

line.i: If, when the poor a∫k charity,
Without a thought you pa∫s them by,
And an∫wer not their claim,
Whate'er excu∫e
You may produce,

stanza.line: It is a burning ∫hame.

line.i: But when, to gratify your pride,
At their reque∫t you turn a∫ide,
And in their ∫orrows pry;
Why then in truth,
'Tis little worth,

stanza.line: Your charity is all my eye.

line.i: And if by chance you freely give,
Accordingly as you receive,
And as they urge their claim,
And then ∫hould cry
And wipe your eye,

stanza.line: It is a crying ∫hame.

chap.p:
Ver. I think I have ∫ucceeded in my Notitium. (Reads from her book) "As we were cro∫∫ing the market-place,
in our way from the auberge to Crow Park, my ears were ∫truck with ∫ome of the mo∫t intere∫ting ∫ounds I ever heard, and which irre∫i∫tibly arre∫ted my foot∫teps. It was a blind beggar, relating in plaintive numbers his melancholy ∫tory. By his ∫ide he had a dumb, but an able advocate, who, with mute eloquence, made the mo∫t forcible appeal to one's charity. A little dog was attached to his ∫ide, who, in a ∫upplicatory po∫ture, joined in the eleemo∫ynary claims of his ma∫ter. I dropped a trifle into the maimed mandicant's hat with a tear -- another was about to follow it, but, a∫hamed of the amiable weakne∫s, I caught the fooli∫h pearl in my handkerchief, and trea∫ured it up in the faithful repo∫itory of my bo∫om." There, I think that was a very happy ∫entence. What is your opinion, Sir Charles?
Sample. I think it is a mi∫erable one, Mi∫s.
Ver. I don't know how I could alter it for the better, unle∫s I were to be "napkin" in∫tead of "handkerchief," for the ∫ake of euphony.
Sample. For who∫e ∫ake, Mi∫s? You may call it "muckinder," if you like it better.

Ver. I really believe he has a mind to laugh at me. I may perhaps introduce a quotation or two. Perhaps, Sir Charles, you can give me a line or two from Horace, or Juvenal, or Tacitus, or --; but that will do when I come to make it out fuller. I think it is per∫picuou∫ly enarrated. Come, Mr. Botani∫t, pray ∫how us the way: the day is getting deciduous. Farewell, my friend; I ∫ympathize in the ∫ecret of your ∫orrows. (Sir Charles and Lydia give him money.)
Speed. I can neither ∫port with his feelings nor my own. (Gives money.)
[Exeunt.
chap.head: AIR.
chap.p: Beggar.

line.i: Be gracious, Heaven! and give reward
To all who thus the poor regard,
And grant that they may never know
The beggar's piercing wants and woe!

chap.title: The Lakers, ACT 1 SCENE III
chap.head: SCENE III.
chap.p: The ∫cene repre∫ents the view cro∫s Derwent-water into the gorge of Borrowdale, and Lowdore water-fall in the di∫tance. The front of the ∫tage repre∫ents Crow Park; about the middle, towards the right hand ∫ide, is Vicar's I∫land, with the hou∫e ∫een ∫ideways, the church in full view. The warm glow of ∫un∫et pervades the land∫cape at fir∫t, and gradually dies away. A ∫hort interval of gloom ∫ucceeds, and the mooon then ri∫es from behind the mountains of Borrowdale.
Veronica enters with a bunch of flowers in her hand, Sir Charles on one ∫ide and Sample on the other, Lydia following, and Speedwell at a di∫tance, carrying Veronica's paraphrenalia.
Ver. A va∫tly curious plant indeed, Mr. Botani∫t! A non-de∫cript, you ∫ay?
Sample. You gather herbs, do you? What, are you anything of a doctor?

Ver. It's a tetrandria tetragynia, I ∫ee. The penducle is articulated, membranaceous, umbelliferous, and tomento∫e; as are al∫o the petioles. The leaves are cauline, petiolated and lanceolate; the corolla is polypetalous; the calyx is monophyllous; the pericarpium is tricoccous, and the ∫emen a nux. We mu∫t give it a name, Mr. Botani∫t. Wait a ∫hort time, and we will call it, from my∫elf, the Portin∫calia. (A∫ide to him.)
Sir Charles. It will be a long time, if we wait till then. (A∫ide.)
Sample. (A∫ide.) What a deal to have to ∫ay to one little bit of a plant! Poor woman! I am afraid ∫he does not know what ∫he's talking about.
Ver. I mu∫t have a ∫pecimen for my hortus ∫iccus. Sir Charles, you don't ∫eem to admire it.
Sample. I don't think much of it indeed, Mi∫s. The colour's ∫o dim, and it's got no ∫mell.
Ver. Why, what botani∫t ever thought of colour or ∫mell in a plant? Speedwell, give me my botany box.
(Puts plants in.) There, take care of it.
Sample. What, I ∫uppo∫e you pre∫s 'em in books? I've ∫een a many do ∫o. But I never could think what they were for, unle∫s it was for making patterns for printing cotton.
Ver. O Sir Charles! I am no ∫tranger to your perfect knowledge of the Linnæan ∫y∫tem.
Sample. I think, Mi∫s, I do know a good deal about linens.
Ver. Inten∫ely a∫toni∫hing! Pray, Sir Charles, do you understand German?
Sample. No, Mi∫s -- not your jargon. (A∫ide.)
Ver. Why every body of ta∫te reads German now. I de∫ign to work up the ∫tory of the Vi∫ionary Hor∫eman on Souther-Fell-∫ide into a ballad in imitation of the German.

Sir Charles. This, Madam, is the celebrated lake of Ke∫wick, or Derwent-water; and the place where we now are, Crow Park, Mr. We∫t's ∫econd ∫tation. It was formerly a glade of ancient oaks, but the wa∫ting hand of avarice has ∫poiled it of its beauties.

Ver. Oh! if one ∫ingle tree had remained, this would have been an unparallelled ∫pot! Stop a minute, if you plea∫e, Mr. Ciceroni, while I get out my pencil to write. (She writes while he gives his account.)

Sir Charles. This ∫pacious ampitheatre of picture∫que mountains, with the pellucid waters lying at their ba∫e, variegated with i∫lands, adorned with wood, or clothed with the ∫weete∫t verdure, pre∫ents a picture as fine as the imagination can form. You look directly acro∫s the lake, for three miles, into the gorge of Borrowdale, where Ca∫tle Crag guards the tremendous pa∫s. To the left is the renowned cataract of Lowdore, now ∫een only as a ∫ilvery ∫treak on the ∫ide of the mountains. A∫hne∫s Crag towers to its left, and Falcon Crag, Wallow Crag, and Ca∫tle Hill, are the mountains which ∫weep beyond them. The fine range of fells to the right (for every crag of every mountain has its name), are Grange-fells, Gold∫cope, Catbells, Newlands, High-∫tyle, Red-pike, and Caw∫ey-pike; Barrow and Swin∫ide below it, with the thick woods of Foe-park at their feet.
This lake is often troubled with what are called "bottom winds:" being a commotion of the water, as if agitated by a ∫udden gu∫t, without any real hurricane or apparent cau∫e.

The i∫land neare∫t to us is Vicar's I∫land; beyond, to the left, Lord's I∫land, once the property of the unfortunate family of Radcliffs Earls of Derwent-water; beyond that, Ramp∫holm; and to the right, beyond
Vicar's, is St. Herbert's I∫land, where he had a hermitage, the foundations of which are now vi∫ible.

Ver. A very happy thought, I declare: quite a beau idée! You mu∫t know, Sir Charles, I have always ∫everal works in hand at the ∫ame time; and, as I always introduce a great deal of de∫cription of ∫cenery in my romances, I keep that in my eye while I am travelling, and write a romance at the ∫ame time with my tours. It is only putting Geneva for Windermere, and, though I have never been abroad, I de∫cribe the ∫cenery exactly as well as if I had been there. But I think I ∫hall lay the ∫cene of my next upon Derwent-water, make St. Herbert to have murdered a pilgrim, who ∫hall turn out to be his brother, and I ∫hall call it "The Horrors of the Hermitage." I can introduce a my∫terious monk of Borrowdale, and ∫hall have fine opportunities of de∫cribing luxuriant groves and bowery lanes, in all the pomp of foliage of beech, birch, mountain-a∫h, and holly. It ∫hall be a romance of the fourteenth century; and the ca∫tle upon Lord's I∫land ∫hall be haunted by an armed head: and, I believe, Lydia, I ∫hall draw my heroine from either you or my∫elf, and make her pa∫∫ionately fon of drawing an botany; ∫he ∫hall be mi∫tre∫s of the Linnæan ∫y∫tem, and then, if I ∫hould make her ∫top, in the mid∫st of her di∫tre∫∫es, to admire the ∫cenery, or gather a plant, it will be perfectly natural.
chap.note: Linnæus lived in the pre∫ent century.
chap.p: Sample. What a villain! murder his brother! Why he didn't murder his brother, did he?
Ver. Not that I know of.
Sample. Why, you wouldn't go to tell lies about the dead then, would you? If his relations were to take it up, they might put you into the pillory for a libel.

Ver. Sir Charles! --But I will not be in∫ulted by him. I will not ∫uffer him to break it off. (A∫ide.) --Va∫tly impre∫∫ive ∫cenery indeed; and quite accordant with ∫olemn tone of feeling at this moment. Pray where is Saddleback?
Sir Charles. Behind you, Madam, beyond Skiddaw, where the ∫un is now ∫etting.
Sample. She carries her ∫addle-bags behind her too when ∫he travels. She's a rum one, as ever I met with.

p.i: Ver. How infinitely ∫ublime! Is not it, Sir Charles?

chap.p: Sample. Yes, Mi∫s, it's very mountainious. You are in the mountain-∫cenery line, I ∫ee.

Ver. Speedwell, give me my gla∫∫es. Where's my Gray? (Speedwell gives gla∫∫es.) Oh! Claude and Pou∫∫in are nothing. By the bye, where's my Claude-Lorrain? I mu∫t throw a Gilpin tint over the∫e magic ∫cenes of beauty. (Looks through the gla∫s.) How gloomily glaring! Now the blue. (Pretends to ∫hiver with cold.) How frigidly frozen! What illu∫ions of vi∫ion! The effect is inexpre∫∫ibly intere∫ting. The amphitheatrical per∫pective of the long land∫cape; the peeping points of the many-coloured crags of the head-long mountains, looking out mo∫t intere∫tingly from the picture∫que luxuriance of the bowery foliage, margining their ruggedne∫s, and feathering the fells; the delightful differences of the heterogeneous ma∫∫es; the horrific mountains, ∫uch ∫cenes of ruin and privation! the turfy hillocks, the umbrageous and repo∫ing hue of the cop∫y lawns, ∫o touchingly beautiful; the limpid lap∫e of Lowdore, the i∫lands coroneting the flood; the water, the ∫oft purple of the pigeon's neck, -- are ∫o many circum∫tances of imagery, which all together combine a picture, which for its ∫entimental beauty and a∫∫emblages of ∫ublimity, I never exceeded in the warme∫t glow of my fancied de∫criptions. And then the imcomparable verdure of the turfy ∫lope we are upon; the water bickering at the ba∫e; the ∫ultry low of the cattle, ∫ipping the clear wave, add a ∫weet pathos to the magical effect of the ∫urrounding ∫cenery. And now the effulgence of the ∫un∫hine land∫cape is fading away, and the blue di∫tances, ∫tealing upon the nearer view, ∫often the ∫ublime ∫everity. --I mu∫t take a ∫ketch. -- Sir Charles, pray come and ∫tand by me for the trunk of an old tree in the foreground. And I beg, Mr. Botani∫t, you and Lydia and Speedwell will form your∫elves into a picture∫que group.
Sample. What, Mi∫s, your are a planner, I ∫ee; and are come to look about you and ∫py your fancies. Pray, Mi∫s, what's this you call your Cordovan?
Ver. My Claude-Lorrain! it is a deceptio vi∫us, an artifice to give the various tints of the changes of weather and ∫ea∫on to the land∫cape.

Sample (looking through.) Well, Mi∫s, if that's your
fancy, I ∫hould think it would be le∫s trouble always to wear a pair of green or yellow ∫pectacles.

Ver. Where's my fi∫hing-∫tool? (Sits down.) Your arm up, if you plea∫e, Sir Charles, for the branch of the tree. Mr. Botani∫t, pray mind the group. Suppo∫e you ∫ing, Mr. Botani∫t? Lydia, you, and perhaps Speedwell, can make up a glee. It will, at lea∫t, give picture∫quene∫s to my de∫cription.
Sir Charles. If the lady will honour us in joining.
chap.head: GLEE.

stanza.line: For forth her interlunar cave
The ∫ilver moon has tipp'd the wave,
And from the di∫tant rocky ∫hore
The falling water's ∫ullen roar,
Borne on the gently ∫welling gale,
Fraught with the ∫weets o'th' flow'ry vale,
Steal on the watchful ear of night,
Diffu∫e a ∫olemn ∫till delight,
Which to tir'd nature, her ∫weet gue∫t,
Imparting, lulls her to her re∫t.

chap.p: Ver. Bravi! Bravi∫∫imi! mio botani∫t cari∫∫imo! You have given energu to my humble talents; your poetry and mu∫ic have given life to their ∫i∫ter art, and I feel my∫elf peculiarly happy in my little ∫ketch. Pray look at it, Sir Charles, and give me your opinion.
Sample. Why, it's no more like the thing than-- Why, you've made the hills more like ∫ugar-loaves--
Ver. If it is not like what it is, it is what it ought to be. I have only made it picture∫que.
Sir Charles. The painter has always a licence to improve upon Nature, where ∫he has erred or been deficient.

Ver. Certainly. I have only given the hills an Alpine form, and put ∫ome wood where it is wanted, and omitted it where it is not wanted: and who could put that ∫ham church and that hou∫e into a picture? It quite antipathizes. I don't like ∫uch meretricious ornaments.
Sample. Why, that place is a tea-garden, I ∫uppo∫e.
Ver. Ha! Ha! ha! you are va∫tly witty, Sir Charles. Not a bad compari∫on of yours.
Sir Charles. Your Lady∫hip forgets the motto to the i∫land: "De gu∫tibus non e∫t di∫putandum."
Ver. Gu∫tibus!-- di∫put!-- Pray, Sir Charles, what does that mean?
Sample. What can I ∫ay? (A∫ide.) Oh, aye!-- "It is not to be di∫puted but there are gu∫ts upon the lake."

Ver. Oh! aluuding to the bottom winds, I ∫uppo∫e. But what has that to do, Mr. Botani∫t, with--? Well-- ∫o, I have made the church an old abbey, the hou∫e a ca∫tle, and the battery an hermitage: I have broken the ∫mooth ∫urface of the water with water-lillies, flags, flowering ru∫hes, water-docks, and other aquatics, making it more of a pla∫hy inundation than a ba∫in of water: then I have put in for the foreground the ∫ingle tree they ought to have left ∫tanding, an ancient tree of remarkable ∫ize and venerable beauty; and have ∫prinkled ∫ome ferms, and burdocks, and gor∫e, and thi∫tles, over this turfy ∫lope. I mu∫t, I think, do this in colours: an orange sky, yellow water, a blue bank, a green ca∫tle, and brown trees, will give it a very fine effect. Sir Charles, how do you like it?

Sample. I can't make neither head nor tail on't. Why, Mi∫s, you might as well draw a head with a goggle eye and a hooked no∫e, a wide mouth and a double chin, and give it a beard and a wig, and call it my picture.

Ver. Sir Charles!-- (A flute is heard at a di∫tance playing the air of "A Shepard once." Veronica drops her book and her pencil, and ∫tands li∫tening.) What a picture∫que ∫ound! The very tune too of my own little ariette. A fine opportunity for di∫playing my vocal powers. (A∫ide.)
chap.head: ARIETTE.

line.i: A lady once her lap-dog lo∫t; Bow, wow, wow, etc.
And ∫he knew it to her co∫t; Bow, wow, wow, etc.
For all in vain the ∫earch was tried, Bow, wow, etc.
Until his mi∫tre∫s had him cried. Bow, wow, etc.
When at la∫t was Pompey found, Bow, wow, etc.
All the hou∫e with grief did ∫ound;
For, oh! ∫ome cruel-hearted wight
A piece of ∫ponge had made him eat.
This at length, in hour accur∫t, Bow, wow, etc.
Swell'd till it did make him bur∫t;
His mi∫tre∫s felt with him the ∫mart,
And for him ∫he did break her heart.

chap.p: Sample. Well, that's a pretty ∫ong, Mi∫s Becky.

Ver. You do me infinite honour, Sir Charles: but I am not altogether in voice this evening.-- He's not ∫o ignorant and ta∫tele∫s as I imagined; but he's an unaccountable man: he's a humouri∫t, I believe. (A∫ide.)
Sir Charles. Does your Lady∫hip ob∫erve a party in a boat making fa∫t to the ∫hore?
Ver. And the da∫hing of the oars breaking the ∫olemn ∫ilence of the evening. Va∫tly fine, indeed. They are going to land here, I declare. How it heightens the intere∫t of the ∫cene!
(A boat makes to the ∫hore of Crow Park. The company in it ∫ing, Veronica and her party join the chorus.)
chap.head: AIR and CHORUS.

line.i: With equal ∫troke, the da∫hing oar
Gains upon the moonlight's ∫hore,
And, with day's bu∫y cares oppre∫t,
Relea∫es us to joy and re∫t.

chap.head: END OF THE FIRST ACT.

chap.title: The Lakers, ACT 2 SCENCE II
chap.head: ACT II.
SCENE I.

head.i: A Room at the Queen's Head.

chap.p: Enter Sir Charles and Speedwell.
If we go on in this manner, Speedwell, it is impo∫∫ible but our ∫chemes mu∫t fail. That ignorant booby, Sample, has no more idea of per∫onating the character he has a∫∫umed, than--
Speed. A cow has of dancing a hornpipe, Sir.

Sir Charles. About as much. How unlike he is to many of his profe∫∫ion! I have conver∫ed with ∫ome who have been men of good ∫en∫e and con∫iderable information; but he ∫eems to think, that it is only putting on the dre∫s, and he becomes the character without farther trouble. If Veronica were not blinded by vanity, folly, and botanic nuptials, ∫he mu∫t have immediately di∫covered the impo∫ition.

Speed. Well, Sir, it is but having recour∫e, at la∫t, to your original plan. Suppo∫e we confe∫s the impo∫ture, ∫ay I am the real Sir Charles Portin∫cale, who a∫∫umed the di∫gui∫e of a ∫ervant to contemplate her charms unob∫erved him∫elf, and that Sample is my ∫ervant? You, Sir, may ∫still retain your character of guide and botani∫t.
Sir Charles. Not a bad ∫cheme, Speedwell: but how ∫hall we get Sample to come into it?

Speed. Why, Sir, there is an argument that I have often known to be made u∫e of, and which is ∫ure of prevailing when all others fail -- the argumentum beculinum. You have acquie∫ced in his impo∫ture ∫o long as it was practicable; and, if he will not come into yours, no doubt the rattan will convince him of the nece∫∫ity of it.
Sir Charles. But the fellow has not talents to per∫onate even a ∫ervant well. Take him from his profits and his patterns, and he has not three ideas beyond.
Speed. If he is awkward, Sir, it is only ∫ending him to the ∫table or the kitchen.

Sir Charles. Of your talents I have no doubt: you ∫o well know my circumstances, my manners, and even my acquirements, from copying over my writings, from books I have recommended to you, and from our conver∫ation on the road, that I question whether your knowledge does not exceed Veronica's. I have often explained to you the outlines of Linnæ Sy∫tem of Vegetables; you therefore can very well

line.i: In filmy, gawfy, go∫∫amery lines,
With lucid language and conceal'd de∫igns,
In ∫weet monandrian monogynian ∫trains
Pant for you mi∫tre∫s in botanic pains.

chap.p: Speed. Bating for hard words, Sir, I think I can match Veronica from the marriage of one male and one female to the clande∫tine marriages of Gretna Green. I thought, as ∫oon as I ∫aw Sample, that it might come to this, and therefore was not idle with my eyes. I think, Sir, ∫ome glances, which I ca∫t upon her, were not thrown away. Here comes the adventurous knight, Sir: we will di∫pel the enchantment which holds him.
Enter Sample.
Sample. Here they are both together. I don't know what to ∫ay. (A∫ide.) Go, Speedwell, and ∫ee the hor∫es taken care of.-- Why don't you go?
Speed. I am no ∫ervant of yours, Sir.
Sample. Why, you ∫aid your∫elf you was.
Speed. When you ∫aid you were Sir Charles Portin∫cale.
Sample. I haven't ∫aid I'm not he.
Speed. But we do, Sir. Here is the true Sir Charles, and you are only an impo∫tor.
Sample. I think he's an impo∫tor.

Sir Charles. Come, Sir, I will explain matters. By mi∫take we exchanged luggage; you got my regimentals, and I your frock and patterns. Deprived of your bu∫ine∫s
by the lo∫s, I ∫uppo∫e you wi∫hed to indemnify your∫elf, by making your fortune with the red coat. You appeared to be making up to the lady I wi∫hed to avoid, and I therefore acquie∫ced in your ∫cheme till you ruined it for your∫elf. You have di∫gu∫ted the lady; and, unle∫s the impo∫ture is confe∫∫ed, ∫he mu∫t di∫cover it her∫elf.
Speed. That is, Sir, you have put on the lion's ∫kin; but the long ears, and your braying, have betrayed you.

Sir Charles. In ∫hort, Sir, it is impo∫∫ible for you to ∫ucceed with her; and, as I have an intere∫t to ∫erve, you mu∫t come into my ∫chemes, in return for my acquie∫cence in yours. My affections are fixed upon the niece, and, were I to declare my∫elf, I ∫hould lo∫e her, and expo∫e my∫elf to the attacks of the aunt. My farther di∫gui∫e is therefore nece∫∫ary, and, to countenance that, my ∫ervant mu∫t declare you an impo∫tor, that he is the true Sir Charles, and you mu∫t con∫ent to pa∫s for his ∫ervant.
Sample. No, don't you think it. I won't demean my∫elf to be a ∫ervant to a ∫ervant. You your∫elf ∫aid I was Sir Charles, and you can't confe∫s having told a lie.

Sir Charles. Then this, Sir, is the alternative. The impo∫ture mu∫t be acknowledged, and you mu∫t relinqui∫h your character. Our luggage mu∫t be re-exchanged; I have my regimentals, and you your frock and patterns; for that mi∫take, we can only be ∫orry for the inconvenience it has occa∫ioned. But, Sir, recollect my hat was left in the care of the landlord, and by what felonious means you become po∫∫e∫∫ed of it, I know not; that you mu∫t explain to the ju∫tice, before whom you will be taken to give an account.

Speed. I beg, Sir, that may be deferred a e ∫hort time. I have received an in∫ult from him; he ∫aid "he would not demean him∫elf to be a ∫ervant of a ∫ervant," meaning me; and I beg that I may fir∫t have an opportunity of ∫atisfying my honour, by calling him out to fight me with pi∫tols, or, if he refu∫es me that ∫atisfaction, I may kick him through Ke∫wick.
Sample. Ju∫tice! Pi∫tols! Kicked through Ke∫wick! Well, but now if I con∫ent?
Sir Charles. I ∫hall be ∫atisfied.
Speed. And ∫o will my honour. It will be a recantation.
Sample. And I ∫hall have my patterns back, and you'll pay me my guinea?
Sir Charles. And ∫atisfy you for any other lo∫s you may have been at.
Speed. And give him an order, Sir, for a piece of cloth, to make wai∫tcoats.

Sample. It's a bargain then; and I ∫hall be glad to get into my own cloathes again; for I feel a little awkward in the∫e. It's harder to be a baronet and a captain than I thought for: I find it is not the ∫carlet coat and gold lace that makes the officer.
Sir Charles. Come, then, Speedwell, you and Mr. Sample mu∫t changed cloathes, and the ∫ooner the di∫covery is made the better.
Speed. I ∫hall be changed in an in∫tant, Sir.
chap.head: SONG.

line.i: The cameleon, it's true,
Changes ∫carlet, green, or blue,
As the ground that by change it ∫hall re∫t on:
In my ma∫ter's livery
His humble ∫lave am I;
If dre∫s'd at my own charge,
I'm the gentleman at large,
And my ma∫ter's own ∫elf with his be∫t on.

chap.p: Sample.

line.i: Well pleas'd, now I've tried,
I'm to lay my rank a∫ide,
And to put off the clothes that I've ∫tept in;
None o'er, that I could hear,
Could make pur∫e of a pig's ear;
Nor can wai∫tcoat and coat
Make the gentleman, I wot;
Nor the hat and cockade make the captain.

chap.p: [Exit with Speedwell.
Sir Charles.

line.i: Wheree'er we turn our eyes,
The world is all di∫gui∫e,
From the fir∫t to the la∫t 'tis deception:
The gentleman lets down,
Dre∫s'd and manner'd as a clown;
The clown his betters apes,
His dre∫s and manner ∫hapes,
And appears of the better de∫cription.

chap.p: Enter Veronica, her hair partly done up in a ∫ilk net, partly hanging loo∫e, a ∫traw hat and green veil, her gown fanta∫tically drawn up.
Ver. Mr. Botani∫t, I am infinitely di∫tre∫∫ed, quite in de∫pair, that we cannot go up Skiddaw this morning.
Sir Charles. Skiddaw has got his nightcap on, Madam, and, were we to go up, we could not ∫ee anything of the ∫urrounding country.

Ver. Well, I'll wait till to-morrow morning, and then I mu∫t go up whether it is fine or not. My tour would be ab∫olutely incomplete without an account of a ride up Skiddaw. I can a∫∫ure you I had dre∫∫ed on purpo∫e for the expedition.
Sir Charles. You would have found that dre∫s rather too light and airy for that cold atmo∫phere.

Ver. Not at all. You mu∫t have taken my Scotch plaid to thrown round me when the air became very thin. A riding-habit would not have done at all in the mountain region; it would have broken in upon the co∫tumé. So I have negligently bound up all my hair in a ∫ilk net, and ∫uffered ∫ome tre∫∫es to e∫cape to play upon my neck and round my countenance. And then the light drapery of my dre∫s, my ∫traw hat, the veil impartially concealing my face, my figure and my air, are what might, I think, be copied for a Grecian nymph.
Sir Charles. (A∫ide) A Grecian nymph in a Scotch plaid, upon the mountains of Cumberland! What a pre∫ervation of the costume!
Ver. However, it will equally accord with the ∫cenery round Derwent-water: I ∫hall appear like the Naïad of Lowdore, or the nympth of Borrowdale.
Sir Charles. Your Lady∫hip is very con∫iderate. Were an arti∫t to be there at the ∫ame time, he mu∫t think him∫elf ∫ingularly happy in having ∫o charming a figure to give life to his land∫cape.

Ver. You are va∫tly obliging, Mr. Botani∫t. I have ∫at once to Mr. Daubly for my picture, which is to be fini∫hed again∫t the next exhibition. I am depicted as the modern godde∫s of botany: I am ∫itting upon the stump of a tree, which has been grafted with innumerable different kinds of ∫hrubs-- the various Syringas: foliis ovato-cordatis, foliis lanceolatis; the Cyti∫as, the Ce∫iras, the Lycias, Loniceras; --which branch round and form a bower over my head. Every flower ∫prings up around me, and a water-fall da∫hes by my ∫ide: I have a full-blown mo∫s-ro∫e upon my head in∫tead of a cap, and mo∫s-ro∫e buds hanging about my neck and ∫houlders, in∫tead of hair. Two wreathes of honey∫uckle twine around my neck and my wai∫t, and under my garment, which is ∫lightly drawn up, in∫tead of a ∫tocking, appears the bark of a tree.
Sir Charles. (A∫ide) The godde∫s of botany with a wooden leg!

Ver. My feet are covered with the con∫erva rivularis, with a large ro∫e upon each of them. In my hand I hold my poem, in twenty cantos, "The Triumph of Botany," while the Arts and Sciences are all paying homage to me. The coup d'œil is exceedingly fine; and I do not recollect to have ∫een anything like it before.
Sir Charles. Not exactly, Madam --except the owl in the ivy-bu∫h. (A∫ide.)

Ver. I mentioned my poem: the ∫ubject is, I think, extremely intere∫ting, and purely cla∫∫ical. You know, Sir, that the botani∫t and the flori∫t have long been at variance; the flori∫t only e∫teems a few, and tho∫e chiefly the double flowers, which the botani∫t con∫iders as mon∫ters. Now I ∫uppo∫e, that, after repeated ho∫tilities, which are the ∫ubject of the former part of the poem, Lonicera ∫empervirens, or trumpet honey∫uckle, is ∫ent, as a herald, to call a parley, and the parties meet on the plain of Enna, ∫o much celebrated by the poets for its flowers and the rape of Pro∫erpina. Flora enters in a wheel-barrow, the garden carriage, driving Hyacinthus, Carnatia, Aurioula, Tulippa, Jonquilla, Ranunculus, and Polyanthus, eight in hand, and is attended
by Cupids, as gardeners, bearing ∫ilver cream-pots and all the prizes given to flori∫ts' fea∫ts. Botania is borne in a tin box, the botani∫ts' conveyance, by eight of her favourites; and, after debating the matter, as we do at Coachmakers' Hall, which introduces an epi∫ode upon that elegant amu∫ement, it is agreed that they ∫hall henceforth unite their powers, and live promi∫cuou∫ly in fields or gardens: a pageant takes place, in which all their adherents appear two and two, attended by Gnomes and Sylphs: Botania and Flora change their cars, and a triumphal ∫ong is chanted to their joint honour.
Sir Charles. How new and how truly poetic is the idea!
Ver. You compliment.-- But ble∫s me! where is Sir Charles? We had better be ∫etting off.
Sir Charles. Which does your Lady∫hip mean? For one was Sir Charles yesterday, and the other to-day; like Archer and Aimwell, they take it by turns, I believe, to be ma∫ter and ∫ervant.
Ver. How!
Sir Charles. Here comes the gentleman to ∫peak for him∫elf. With your permi∫∫ion, I will wait upon the young lady, and give her ∫ome farther in∫ight into your favourite ∫cience.
Ver. By all means. We will overtake you towards Lowdore.
[Exit Sir Charles.
Enter Speedwell, in regimentals.
Speed. Aba∫hed with ∫hame, I am come, mo∫t lovely of women, to implore your pardon, for an impo∫ition which I have practi∫ed upon you.
Ver. How! Speedwell!

Speed. I am, Madam, the unhappy and the happy man who would no longer be thought Speedwell, but Sir Charles Portin∫cale. Willing to witne∫s, unob∫erved by the lovely Beccabunga Veronica, tho∫e charms of which the world ∫peaks ∫o highly, but which I believed it impo∫∫ible for mortal to be endowed with, I changed characters with my ∫ervant, and viewed them at humble di∫tance. Who could ∫ee, and not love? Have pity upon me then, and, in ∫ealing my doom, remember that my death follows your refu∫al, and my happine∫s your gracious conde∫cen∫ion.
Ver. And ∫ you think I have ∫o little penetration as not to know you?
Speed. I hope ∫o. (A∫ide.)
Ver. Is it po∫∫ible that the accompli∫hments of Sir Charles Portin∫cale could really be concealed under the appearance of a menial?
Speed. She has not di∫covered us, I hope. (A∫ide.)

Ver. No, Sir Charles, I have more penetration that that: though you ∫eem to think not, by attempting to pa∫s your∫ vulgar, illiterate ∫ervant upon me as your∫elf. That chivalric air of yours is not to be imitated. I can a∫∫ure you that I was not in∫en∫ible to the dear "∫peechle∫s me∫∫ages" which I received from your eyes: but you know, Sir Charles, if I had not given into it, I ∫hould have ∫poilt one of the be∫t incidents that could po∫∫ibly occur for my tour. It is a mo∫t picture∫que incident, and perfectly cla∫∫ical. The heathen deities, you know, often changed their forms, to pur∫ue their amours, and your royal name∫ake travelled, like you, in di∫gui∫e, ∫ecretly to witne∫s the charms of his intended.
Speed. How amiable is this forgiving kindne∫s! Yet, how ∫hall I apologi∫e for the in∫ults offered by my ∫ervant?

Ver. O dear, don't mention them. His vulgarity and po∫itivity were a little di∫tre∫∫ing; and, as I am not a me∫embryanthemum cry∫tallinum, I could not forbear now and then ∫howing a little ∫pontaneity of ∫cintillation: I am certainly pho∫phore∫cent, like the Tropœolum; but your ∫ubmi∫∫ion di∫arms me.
Speed. Unexampled goodne∫s! Then let me hope that the flame which warms my heart is an∫wered by a kindred blaze in yours.

Ver. Wel, then, I will be equally frank with your∫elf: in ∫hort, Sir Charles, I am not willing to be ∫olely female all my like, like the capri∫ca. And what woman, when offered the hand of Sir Charles Portin∫cale, could refu∫e it?
Speed. O ∫ay, when will you complete my happine∫s? Were I to lo∫e you --were you to alter you mind--

Ver. Never, Sir Charles --And to convince you --But money can be no object to you --Yet, Sir Charles, I have a tolerable fortune, and, to convince you of my love, I in∫i∫t upon your taking a bond for my forfeiting it all, in ca∫e of a refu∫al.
Speed. By no means. Recollect, I have once deceived you.

Ver. I beg you will not ∫ay ∫o, Sir Charles; you have not deceived me. I merely humoured the deception for the ∫ake of the incident. If you refu∫e to take it, Sir Charles, I ∫hall think you are not ∫incere. Here is pen, ink, and paper, and you ∫hall have it immediately. (Sits down and writes.)

Speed. Am I to blame for this? She makes love, to her own en∫naring. (A∫ide.) But, Madam, how do you know that I am not ∫till an impo∫tor? Are you certain I am Sir Charles Portin∫cale? If hereafter you ∫hould find I have deceived you--

Ver. Then blame me, and I'll forgive you. (Gives a bond.) Do you think I could, even for a moment, have encouraged that vulgar fellow, but out of regard for his charming prototype? I declare, I remind myself to Collin∫onia:

stanza.line: Two brother ∫wains, of Collin's gentle name,

line.i: The ∫ame their features, and their forms the ∫ame,

stanza.line: With rival love for fair Collinia ∫igh,

line.i: Knit the dark brow, and roll th' unsteady eye:

stanza.line: With ∫weet concern the pitying beauty mourns,
And ∫ooths, with ∫impering ∫miles, the pair by turns.

chap.p: Speed. Accompli∫hed charmer! How ∫hall I repay this increa∫ing debt of love?
Ver. Let us be walking, Sir Charles. Let me take your arm. From the ∫oft voice of love we mu∫t turn to the ∫ublime and terrible of nature: but, Sir Charles, I fear you do not love me?
Speed. Ne'er was vegetable love ∫o con∫tant to his mi∫tre∫s.
chap.head: AIR.

line.i: When bourne upon the buoyant air,

stanza.line: Diœcius ∫eeks his amorous fair,

line.i: O'er woods and wilds he takes his flight,
From early morn to late∫t night,
Sees thou∫and beauties round him ri∫e,
Yet ∫teers, with undiverted eyes,
Till, having found his fair-one's charms,
He re∫ts within her peaceful arms.

chap.p: Veronica.

stanza.line: Thus Valli∫neria patient bides

line.i: The flowing of the welcome tides,
Which, as they onward gently move,
Bring her glad tidings of her love;
And, as the fragrant zephyrs ∫weep
The bo∫om of the ∫welling deep,
Her love appears in blooming charms,
And ha∫tes to her expecting arms.

chap.p: [Exeunt.

chap.title: The Lakers ACT II SCENE II
chap.head: SCENE II.
chap.p: On the Banks of Derwent-water.
Enter Sir Charles and Lydia.

Lydia. Though you have explained your motives, Sir Charles, for this extraordinary conduct, and I, in part, admit the ju∫tice of it; yet, be a∫∫ured, I never can bring my∫elf to ∫ee my aunt ill treated or expo∫ed, notwith∫tanding her ∫trange and har∫h conduct towards me. Believe me, Sir Charles, the time I pa∫s with her, and the painful obligations which ∫he confers upon me, are almo∫t too much for a mind not ∫tronger than my own.
Sir Charles. The ∫uffer me to relea∫e you from your ∫lavery, and confer an obligation upon me, by taking your liberty at my hands.
chap.head: AIR.

line.i: Thus when, un∫helter'd, we expo∫e
To wa∫ting ∫torms the blu∫hing ro∫e,
It droops its lovely head:
Oppre∫s'd by grief and fretting tears,
By ∫low degrees its beauty wears,
And all its charms are fled.
But ∫hake the wa∫ting tears away,
And let it hail the ∫olar ray,
No more it meets the ground;
Again it lifts its lovely head,
With nature's choice∫t beauty ∫pread,
And breathes delight around.

chap.p: Lydia. Your generous conduct, Sir Charles, demands my warme∫t gratitude. You have been plea∫ed to ∫elect me from amoung∫t the thou∫ands you have ∫een; and, not to be ∫en∫ible of the honour, would betray a heart incapable of love or of reason. To become your wife will be my honour, as well as my hapine∫s; yet, in accepting that, I mu∫t not forget, that, though I at times experience har∫h treatment from my aunt, under who∫e care I am placed, till I become of age to be my own mi∫tre∫s, I am under obligations to her; and, though no authority ∫hall force me to an engagement again∫t my own inclination, nor cruelty deprive me of the object of my affections, I will not buy my own happine∫s at the expen∫e of hers, nor ∫ee her expo∫ed without re∫enting it.

Sir Charles. How noble, to be thus folicitous for tho∫e who are unmindful of our welfare! To ∫hield my∫elf from the vain attacks of your aunt, has been the ∫ole motive for the∫e transformations. To prevent her from expo∫ing her∫elf, you your∫elf mu∫t well know is impo∫∫ible. But if, in avoiding her attacks, and attempting to forward the great object of my happine∫s, I ∫hould be guilty of di∫honour or inju∫tice, may I, as my puni∫hment, bring down the mi∫ery upon my own head, which I would have brought upon another.
Lydia. Then what is your de∫ign in thus continuing your di∫gui∫e, and of the artifice of your ∫ervant?

Sir Charles. To gain time to ∫ecure the affections and the hand of my Lydia. But, were my ∫ervant even to prevail upon your aunt to accept him, my life on it! the man has worth to a∫pire to a nobler choice. He is my ∫ervant, and he is my friend.
Lydia. It is in your honour I confide.

Sir Charles. But I ∫hall take you, Lydia, only from one ∫trife to another, and from one tyranny to perhaps a greater re∫traint. Can you bear the inconvenience and the tumult of a camp, and the uncertainty and hazard of joining your fate with a ∫oldier's?
Lydia. Yes, when that ∫oldier generou∫ly joins his fate with mine.
chap.head: AIR.

line.i: When the fife and the drum ∫hall mu∫ter the band,
And the troops all for marching prepare,
When you, at their head, give the word of command,
And the trumpet's ∫hrill clang rends the air:
With a heart beating high in re∫pon∫e to their notes,
Whil∫t their banners are flouting in the wind,
And the full tide of war in the atmo∫phere floats,
Pleas'd I'll follow in ∫afety behind.
If the battle ∫hould rage, in the mid∫t of the ∫trife,
To the guardians of Virtue I'll cry,
To re∫tore you, unharm'd, to the arms of your wife,
Or with you be permitted to die.

chap.p: Sir Charles. Then will my Lydia con∫ent to entru∫t her∫elf to my honour? A few hours will remove us to the place, where there can be no impediment to our union; and we may then return to your aunt without any further apprehensions.

Lydia. By no means. Declare your∫elf at once, your title and your intentions. When ∫he finds you re∫olved not to accept her, ∫he will be proud in your alliance with me; and we ∫hall not find any further bars to our happine∫s.

line.i: When two fond hearts in mutual love
Their fortunes firm unite,
Dear is the bli∫s they then approve,
Unruffled their delight:
For Rea∫on then, with ∫anction wi∫e,
Reveres their plighted troth,
And Angels, bending from the ∫kies,
Are witne∫s to their oath.

chap.title: The Lakers ACT 2 SCENE III
chap.head: SCENE III.

p.i: A Room at the Queen's Head.

chap.p: Enter Bob Kiddy, Anna Katharina, and Landlord.
Bob. Where are aunt and coz, and the captain?
Landlord. They are gone to Lowdore water-fall, Sir. There is a party in their room eating a ∫andwich; as ∫oon as they are gone, I will ∫how you up.
Bob. Yup-a-hey, Kate! Put down the things, and go about your bu∫ine∫s, my little galloper. I ∫how'd you what good driving is, I think. I rode the hor∫e my∫elf, drove po∫t: rather a crack-thing that.
Landlord. A gentleman be his own po∫t boy! (A∫ide.)
Anna. Kate! my name's Anna Katharina.
Bob. You are aunt's Anna Katharina, as you call you∫elf, but you are my Kate; and a ∫weet cate you are too.
Landlord. I'll ∫how the young woman to my wife.
Anna. Young woman! Anna Katharina, Sir.
[Exit with Landlord.

Bob. Gone to ∫ee the water-fall! that's rum enough. I'll ∫ee a good ∫tream of wine before the day's out. Mu∫t have a ∫andwich before dinner. Was rather pecki∫h at breakfa∫t- crop∫ick from la∫t night. Here, waiter.
(Enter Landlord.) Mu∫t have a ∫andwich and a draught of porter. Have you got a tennis-court here?
Landlord. No, Sir.
Bob. Or a billiard-table?

Landlord. Not a billiard-table! Why, I never knew ∫uch a place in my life. Not a billiard-table! Has any body got a bear, or a badger to bait? or fighting cocks? Famous fun that. --Like to ∫ee 'em challenge: cock, cock, cock, coo. (Imitates cocks.) Then they peck the ground, and come on in a ∫tyle. --Deadly fine fun is a Wel∫h main.
Landlord. Deadly indeed, Sir; for it co∫ts many poor creatures their lives. --No, Sir, we have nothing of that kind here. --This is ∫ome cruel coward. (A∫ide.)
Bob. Why, how do people pa∫s their time here? What have you got to eat?
Landlord. The lady ordered dinner at four. There is ∫ome of the red trout--
Bob. Plague on't, the bottle of fi∫h ∫auce was broken when the Sociable came down. I never travel without fi∫h ∫auce. The chow-chow is all gone too.
Landlord. A leg of nice mutton, Sir--
Bob. Let's have ∫ome currant-jelly with it.
Landlord. And a couple of roa∫t fowls.
Bob. Broil one of 'em, and pepper it well. Make a devil of it, and let's have the be∫t wine in your cellar.
Landlord. And then you'll make a devil of your∫elf. (A∫ide.) It ∫hall be as you order, Sir. We've a nice grou∫e in the pantry, Sir.
Bob. Does it ∫tink?
Landlord. As ∫weet as a nut, Sir.
Bob. Then keep it till it does, for then aunt and coz won't touch it; and I ∫hall have it all to my∫elf. Bring me a gla∫s of cherry brandy, and get me a ∫andwich.
Landlord. Directly, Sir. We've ∫ome nice hung beef in the hou∫e.
chap.head: SONG.
chap.p: Bob.

line.i: Let others travel far and near,
To view each hill and valley,
To ∫ee how different ∫cenes appear,
And wherein 'tis they tally:
My purpo∫e is where I begin
To ∫ee each country's produce,
To tell the merits of each inn,
And what I find of no u∫e.
The ruin'd ca∫tle ∫ome admire,
Which lets in wind and weather;
I like the ∫nug and blazing fire,
When ∫helter'd altogher.
And though a lake is well enough
For ∫ailing or for rowing,
I better like the right good ∫tuff

stanza.line: That ∫ets me off a rouing.

line.i: Some ninnies go around the world
In ∫earch of fine adventures,
From port to port by weather hurl'd,
Till all their fortune's ∫pent thus.
From port to port too I will go,
From Tenerife to Li∫bon;
And ∫o of wine I get enow,
Why faith to me it is one.

chap.p: Enter Landlord, with Fir∫t and Second Pede∫trian, dre∫∫ed in ∫ailor's jackets and trow∫ers, knap∫acks at their backs, umbrellas, etc.
Landlord. Two gentlemen on foot, Sir. You room will be ready immediately.
[Exit.
Bob. Foot! Poor devils!
1∫t Ped. We do not interrupt you, I hope, Sir?
Bob. No. What you've walked, have you? Why do you walk as ∫ailors?
1∫t Ped. The dre∫s is light, and well adapted for travelling.
Bob. But a'n't you afraid of being taken up?
2d Ped. No, Sir. We injure no one, why ∫hould any one injure us?
Bob. You mu∫t be a little tired and foot-∫ore, I think?
1∫t Ped. Neither, Sir; we are u∫ed to it, and ∫uffer no inconvenience whatever.
Bob. U∫ed to it! What, you've come ∫ome way?
2n Ped. Some hundreds of miles, Sir.
Bob. What, going home? or going to ∫ee your friends?
2n Ped. Neither, Sir! Travelling for plea∫ure.
Bob. That's a good one! Travelling on foot for plea∫ure!
1∫t Ped. Yes, Sir.
Bob. Short of ca∫h, perhaps? But then you might have ∫taid at home.

2d Ped. But not have ∫een the world there. My friend and my∫elf, being anxious to ∫ee other places be∫ides our own, and other men and other manners than tho∫e of our own confined circle, travel thus, at a light expen∫e, in ∫earch of knowledge and amu∫ement.
Bob. Why, they're crack'd. What then, if you had money, you wouldn't walk?
2d Ped. Not altogether that, Sir. We might perhaps afford what others might e∫teem accommodations, but which would be none to us.
Bob. I wouldn't give a penny to travel without hor∫es and ∫ervants.

1∫t Ped. That involves a great expen∫e. But, in not having them, we have fewer troubles, and ∫ecure our independance. A hor∫e requires care and attendance; he may knock up, he may fall lame: a ∫ervant will ∫carcely live upon le∫s than a moderate gentleman; he will not perhaps ∫ubmit to the fatigue, he may impo∫e upon you, he may cheat you, he may be impatient. Our own feelings tell us when we ∫hould re∫t, and when we ∫hould go on; we carry the flight changes we want at our backs; we ∫tand in need of no other ∫ervice, and have no trouble nor inconvenience re∫pecting our conveyance;
it is always ready when we are, and re∫t repairs any flight injury it may undergo during the day, and they which carry us are always comfortably lodged when we are. Exerci∫e ∫ecures appetite and ∫leep; the contemplation of the works of nature and of man affords amu∫ement and exerci∫e to the mind, and health re∫ults from both.
chap.head: AIR.
chap.p: Fir∫t Ped.

line.i: In viewing Nature's varied ∫cenes,
Sweet is the plea∫ure they impart,
For Rea∫on ∫carce has better means
To ∫often and improve the heart.

chap.p: Second Ped.

line.i: From exerci∫e what ∫pirits flow!
Sweet is the meal that Hunger finds,
And ∫weet the ∫lumbers that we know,
The calm repo∫e of tranquil minds.

chap.p: Both.

line.i: Then let us range the vallies ∫till,
And o'er the mountain's ∫ummit wind,
Trace with delight the gurgling rill,
And ∫till pre∫erve the tranquil mind.

chap.p: Bob. Quizical enough! travel for health and improvement! Why, I never care about either. Aunt gives about her, to be ∫ure; but I never look at any thing but the ∫tables and the larder. And what have you learnt, pray?

2d Ped. We have learnt, Sir, that human nature is pretty much the ∫ame in every place and in every condition. All ranks have their plea∫ures and their pains, their virtues and vices. My Lord ri∫ks his guineas at faro, and the clown his halfpence at chuck. My Lord gets drunk with wine, and murders his friend in a duel; the clown gets intoxicated with ale, he quarrels with his pot companion, and breaks his rib, or beats out an eye in a boxing-bout; if he does not murder him, it is the difference of weapons, not the ∫uperior virtue of the clown,
which ∫pares him. Mi∫s dances at the ball, and the next morning elopes with the captain; the country la∫s dances her jog at the fair with her ∫weetheart, and the next morning has as little hone∫ty as her ∫uperior in rank. My Lord profanes his ∫abbath at the card-table or the concert, the clown at to∫∫ing-up, or in the ale-house. If the rich do not ∫eek opportunities of doing good, the poor neglect them when they occur. It is certain we have all our vices, and I hope we have all ∫ome virtues.

Bob. I ∫hould think now you might pick up ∫omething as you travel, by preaching from the top of a beer-barrel, or from a hollow tree. Come, I'll treat you with a bottle of wine a-piece, if you like it, and give you a bit of dinner into the bargain.
1∫t Ped. We thank you, Sir, for you offer, but beg leave to decline it.
Bob. Well, I don't under∫tand you together. Refu∫e a bottle of wine! If you'd offer me two, I'd drink 'em both.

1∫t Ped. Every thing with us depends upon health, and we mu∫t not ri∫k that by intemperance. Nor is it for people in our ∫ituation to pay three ∫ixpence a bottle for wine. Without wine we can travel better; and, what is more, we can travel farther.
Bob. Why, you ∫trave your∫elves.
2d Ped. That would be as bad, Sir. No, Sir, we live well; but plain: and in a draught of good ale we find more health and nouri∫hment, than in the liquid fire retailed in bottles at an inn.
Bob. Well, I find I can make nothing of you, and ∫o good bye. --Of all the quizzes I've ever ∫een, commend me to your pede∫trians. (A∫ide, and exit.)
1∫t Ped. Well, Frank, we'll treat our∫elves with a bit of dinner, and then for the wonders of Ke∫wick.
2d Ped. With all my heart.
[Exeunt.

chap.title: The Lakers, ACT 2 SCENE IV
chap.head: SCENE IV.
chap.p: Enter Veronica, Speedwell, Lydia, and Sir Charles.

Ver. What delightful ∫cenes of pa∫toral and ∫ylvan ∫implicity, contra∫ted with the terrific mountains which ∫urround
them! They remind me of the days of Arcadian innocence. The∫e peaceful cots, ∫eque∫tered in the gloom of beech and ∫ycamore, form an umbrageous land∫cape, which, ∫et off by the umpurpling and downy hue of the clouds, with occa∫ional interventions of gay gleams of light, are ∫o many circum∫tances of imagery, which give a magical effect to the whole, well according with my ∫olemn tone of feeling at this moment. I am afraid, Sir Charles, I may be tautologous; but it is ∫carcely po∫∫ible, in repeated de∫criptions, to avoid it. Pray, Mr. Botani∫t, have you have of the per∫icaria ∫iliquo∫a, or noli me tangere, growing hereabouts? It is one of the few plants I am unacquainted with.

Sir Charles. The touch me not! It is found in great plenty near Windermere. It is a pity that your Lady∫hip is ∫o entirely unacquainted with it, as it is a curious plant, and well worthy of your attention. --This, Madam, is the delightful village of Grange, celebrated for its ho∫pitality to Mr. Gray; and this the gorge of Borrowdale, who∫e terrible appearance intimidated him from exploring father the∫e fine∫t of ∫cenes.
Ver. Don't ∫peak, le∫t the agitation of the air ∫hould loo∫en the rocks about, and bring down a ma∫s that would overwhelm us.

Speed. Many a per∫on, Madam, has brought ruin upon him∫elf by ∫peaking, when he ∫hould have held his tongue. --And though ruin ∫hould hang over her head, ∫ooner than hold her tongue, a woman e'en lets it have its own way. (A∫ide.)
