Ver. A fine opportunity for a peep into pa∫toral life, and an incident to ∫ecure Sir Charles's heart for ever. (A∫ide.) Sir Charles, my heart beats in fond ∫ympathy with the innocence of the∫e uncorrupted mountaineers--
Speed. Their innocence is of a very ∫ingular nature then. (A∫ide.)
Ver. To eat oat-cake and butter-milk in the peaceful man∫ion --I have got ∫ome tongue in my pocket.
Speed. Yes, ∫he always carries a tongue with her. (A∫ide.)
Ver. Give me your arm.
Speed. You had better not give way to this amiable ∫en∫ibility: let me lead you back to the hotel at Lowdore.
Ver. Not for the world --my too ∫u∫ceptible heart--
Speed. It is ∫u∫ceptible, I believe, of twice as much as any other. (A∫ide.)
Sir Charles. Hard by is the habitation of an ho∫pitable herd∫man; his door is ever open to tho∫e who will plea∫e enter it.
chap.head: AIR.

line.i: Beneath the tall beech that grows hard by the tide,
Will Hearty, a plain hone∫t ∫oul, does re∫ide;
He's a friend to the rich, he's a friend to the poor,
For ne'er on di∫tre∫s hath he yet ∫hut his door.
He's a board that is ∫pread with his plain whole∫ome fare,
And a cellar affording a jug of good beer;
If them∫elves Thir∫t or Hunger before him pre∫ent,
Will Hearty will always their wi∫hes prevent.
But if the rich or the noble he's ∫ought,
The choice∫t of dainties before him are brought,
And, while they thus honour his plain friendly board,
Will Hearty is happy, and great as a lord.

chap.p: Ver. Lead me there. Oh, Sir Charles! the∫e over-coming ∫cenes of the grand and the ∫ublime--
Speed. Let me draw a veil over your eyes, and you won't ∫ee them--
Ver. Lead me into the peaceful cot--Oh!--(Faints.)
Speed. Mr. Guide, a∫∫i∫t me with the lady.

Sir Charles. This way, if you plea∫e: here, under the lowly ∫hed of poverty, we ∫hall find the princely virtue of compa∫∫ion, and get a∫∫i∫tance to recover this amiable ab∫entee-- That ∫entence mu∫t, I think, be put down in the tour. (A∫ide.) -- Madam, may we de∫ire your a∫∫i∫tance?
Lydia. No doubt my aunt will ∫oon recover: a bit of oat-cake and a draught of butter-milk will awaken her from this tran∫itory trance.
[Exeunt.
Haymaker. Come, my lads and la∫∫es, the day is warm, and labour makes us thir∫ty; a draught of beer will refre∫h us. Bring the keg, and we;ll ∫ing a roundel as it circulates.
chap.head: AIR and CHORUS.

line.i: The ∫outhern breeze that through the dale,
While new-mown meadows ∫weets exhale,
Breaths fragrance and delight around:
While upward ∫oars the ∫hrill-gorg'd lark,
The village ∫wains attentive hark,
And catch the cheerful ∫ound:
With him they hail the ∫un's bright ray,
And labour cheerly through the day.

chap.head: END OF THE SECOND ACT.

chap.title: The Lakers ACT 3 SCENE 1
chap.head: ACT III.
SCENE I.

p.i: A Room at the Queen's Head.

chap.p: Enter Sample and Anna.

I DESIRES, Sir, you won't follow me about ∫o: I thought ye had been a gentleman; but, as ye be only a gentleman's gentleman, ye be not for my money, and I can a∫∫ure ye: be∫ides, ye don't under∫tand botamy.
Sample. No, how ∫hould I?

Anna. Oh, ∫uch an enlightened ∫tudy! ∫uch hard names! Why, do you know I was a whole day larning a ∫ingle word, and forgot it again the next morning. Another word, to be ∫ure, I larnt in an hour; but then I forgot it the next minute. But my mi∫tre∫s recollects every thing; ∫he is a great ∫chollard. Such curious truths too contained in it --why, plants are all men and women.
Sample. Aye, there are ∫weet-williams; I'm a ∫weet-william. And coxcombs, and painted ladies, and lords and ladies, and naked ladies, like your modern fine ladies, and--
Anna. No, no, I mean that they drink and ∫leep, and are like man and wife.
Sample. What, ∫leep in the ∫ame bed?
Anna. Yes, and in different beds, and live ∫ometimes in different hou∫es.
Sample. Have a ∫eparate maintainance! They mu∫t be your fa∫hionable plants then. What, and ∫ome have their mi∫∫es, I reckon, as well as their wives?
Anna. Oh yes! a great many: and ∫ome ladies have their gallants too.
Sample. Upon my word, Mi∫s, a very pretty ∫tudy this ∫eems to be that you've learnt: I can't ∫ay I ∫hould much like my wife to know any thing about it.
Anna. That you'll find a difficult matter to get one who's ignorant of it; for all ladies that know any thing ∫tudy botamy now: and, if I hadn't de∫pi∫ed ye before, I do now for you ignorance.

Sample. And yet, I don't know, I like her very well; and if ∫he'll make a good wife in other re∫pects, I'll take care ∫he doesn't get to her gallants, and to living in a different hou∫e. (A∫ide.) Now, if I was to love you, and give you a proof of my love?
Anna. I can't like nobody that isn't larned.

Sample. It ∫eems to be the way to get wives by telling lies: I'm telling a lie by ∫aying I'm a ∫arvant, and one lie isn't wor∫e than another. (A∫ide.) Now ∫uppo∫e I was really a gentleman, and only made my∫elf a ∫arvant to ∫ee if I liked you? Suppo∫e I was a baronet?
Anna. A what!
Sample. Suppo∫e I was Sir Charles Portin∫cale, and di∫gui∫ed my∫elf to ∫ee how I liked you, and win your heart?
Anna. Sir Charles Portin∫cale, that danced with my young mi∫tre∫s at Lanca∫ter?
Sample. And liked you better than ∫he, and ∫o told her I was a ∫arvant, to get away from her.
Anna. Why, you don't ∫ay ∫o? And ∫he wouldn't have ye, becau∫e ye was a ∫arvant? A proud minx!
Sample. But don't you ∫ay a word about it.

Anna. And ∫o you really love me? --This comes now to my young lady for not knowing the ∫en∫ual ∫y∫tem. He likes me be∫t, yhough he don't know why. (A∫ide.) And do you mean to marry me, Sir Charles? I've got ∫ome money, I can a∫∫ure you; I've ∫aved two hundred pounds in ∫arvice.
Sample. Ju∫t ∫erve to ∫et me up in a nice little ∫hop of my own. (A∫ide.) To be ∫ure I do. We'll be married directly.
Anna. And then I ∫hall really be a lady?
Sample. Yes, you'll be my lady.
Anna. And you won't be a∫hamed of owning me?
Sample. No, if you leave off your ∫trange talk about men and women, and mi∫∫es and gallants.
Anna. Aye, that I will. --A woman never thinks any promi∫e ∫he makes at marriage binding. (A∫ide.)
Sample. Well, then let's break a ∫ixpence upon it. Come.
chap.head: AIR.
chap.p: Sample.

line.i: This ∫ixpence break
For my dear ∫akel
'Twill join our hearts together:
As ∫ure as fate,
You're then my Kate,
In matrimonial tether.

chap.p: Anna.

line.i: I hold it true,
When broke in two,
Our hearts in one combine-a;
But 'tis not fate
Can make me Kate,
I'm Anna Katharina.

chap.p: Anna. There, it's a match. (They break a ∫ixpence.)
Enter Bob Kiddy.
Bob. What's a match, my little pu∫s?
Anna. Match! O dear --why only for me and my fellow-∫arvant to play a game of cards.
Bob. You fellow-∫arvant! Why, it's the officer that brough aunt and coz. What, you're a poacher, Captain?
Sample. I mu∫tn't tell him who I am. (A∫ide to Anna.) I'm no Captain, Sir, but the Captain's man.
Bob. No! Why, you'd regimentals on when you took up aunt and coz.
Sample. Had I? O aye! My ma∫ter de∫ired me to wear his cloathes to air them.
Bob. That's a lie, I believe.
Sample. Do you give me the lie, Sir?
Bob. No, I don't ∫ay it is a lie; only that I believe it is one.
Sample. I believe he's only a bully. I'll frighten him. (A∫ide.) Why then, you lie, Sir.
Bob. I believe he daresn't fight, though he talks ∫o big. He's no great ∫hakes, I think. (A∫ide.) Do you give me the lie, Sir.
Sample. No; you take it your∫elf. If you'd given me the lie, I'd have pulled you by the no∫e. --I fancy I'm as ∫trong as he. (A∫ide.)
Bob. You ∫hould fight me if you was a gentleman; but, as you are only a ∫ervant, I ∫hall cane you.
Sample. But I am a gentleman. I am the officer.
Bob. Then you've told a lie, in ∫aying you was his ∫ervant.
Sample. Do you tell me then that I lie?
Bob. No; you tell your∫elf ∫o. But you gave me the lie, and ∫hall fight me.
Sample. I do know ∫omething of ∫parring. Come on, then.
Bob. Why, you blackguard! you don't think I'll box with you? You ∫hall fight me with pi∫tols.
Sample. So, now I've got into another ∫crape. I don't think he dare fire. (A∫ide.) Very well, I'm not afraid.
Bob. He mu∫t be though, by ∫aying he's not. (A∫ide.) Well then, get a ∫econd, and I'll meet you.
Sample. Why, he's my ∫econd, for I've e∫caped fighting with one before. --I'll get Speedwell to go with me, and perhaps he won't let us fight. (A∫ide.) Very well, I'm your man.
Anna. No --No -- you mu∫tn't fight. If you kill him, you'll kill --Oh!--Oh!--Oh! (Sobbing.)
Sample. Aye, ∫he'll take care to prevent us. A∫ide.) I'll be with you in a crack. You've in∫ulted my honour, and mu∫t ∫atisfy me.
[Exit.

Bob. I'll kill him, if that will be any ∫atisfaction to him. But it'll not be any to me to be kill'd. I'd better not have provoked him. For though he may be only a bully, yet he may fight, and he may kill me. --Well! that's a good thought. --I know what I'll do, and then I ∫hall be ∫ure to be ∫afe. Here come the pede∫trians. I'll get one of them to be my ∫econd, perhaps he'll make it up.
Enter Pede∫trians.

Well, my lads, how are you? I'm glad to ∫ee you again.
So you wouldn't crack a bottle with me? Well; now I want you to do me a good turn.
Anna. Oh! you bloodthir∫ty brute! I'll have you bound over to you good behaviour.
1∫t Ped. That would be no very ea∫y matter, I believe.
Anna. (Sobbing.) But he ∫ha'n't fight. I'll go and I'll -- He's only a ∫arvant, and he's no right to be killed as a gentleman.
chap.head: AIR.

line.i: Oh dear, my heart I'm ∫ure will break!
If you away his life ∫hould take,
Then all my hopes are gone;
For then my days, ah! I'm afraid,
I ∫hall be forc'd to pa∫s a maid,
And never cea∫e to mourn.

chap.p: [Exit.
1∫t Ped. What is the cau∫e of this, Sir? A woman in tears, and you not attempt to dry them!
Bob. Why, I'm going to kill her ∫weetheart, I believe, and I want you to a∫∫i∫t me.
1∫t Ped. Kill her ∫weetheart, and want me to a∫∫i∫t you!
Bob. Yes, I'm going to fight him, and want you to be my ∫econd.
1∫t Ped. Fight a duel, and wi∫h me to be your ∫econd! No, Sir.
Bob. Why, you a'n't afraid, are you?
1∫t Ped. I am, Sir. I am afraid to break the laws of my country and my Maker.

Bob. But a man of honour doesn't care for either. Be∫ides, if I ∫hould kill him, the coroner's inque∫t will only bring it in "man∫laughter;" or if they ∫hould bring it in "murder," depend upon it we can manage to have a flaw in the indictment.
1∫t Ped. And, Sir, would you implicate me in a crime, for which I may run the hazard of my own life?
Bob. Why, you're only to be my ∫econd. I don't want to fight you.
1∫t Ped. But he, Sir, who looks on, and calmly beholds his fellow-creatures commit murder, is acce∫∫ary to the crime, and mu∫t an∫wer it to his offended country with his life.
Bob. He talks very fine. He's my man. I'm ∫ure if I pre∫s him, he'll put a ∫top to it. (A∫ide.) Well, but you wouldn't mind your life for a friend?
1∫t Ped. A friend! You offered me a bottle of wine! Sir, for a true friend, nay, in a good cau∫e, I would ri∫k my life for my enemy; but I will not hazard it in being ∫econd in a duel.
Bob. But he gave me the lie.
1∫t Ped. I would not have accepted the ill language of one, who ∫o little knew what good breeding was.
Bob. But he threatened to pull my no∫e. What can I do in that ca∫e?
1∫t Ped. If you really fear, go with your no∫e ∫oaped.
Bob. Why, he's laughing at me. I can tell you, Sir, I can always laugh at tho∫e that laugh at me.
1∫t Ped. Then, Sir, you are the laughing philo∫opher, and laugh at the whole world. You mu∫t lead a very merry life.
Bob. Yes, pretty well for that. I keep it up. So you won't ∫tand my friend?
1∫t Ped. What is it you want, Sir?
Bob. I want ∫ati∫faction, and you to ∫ee that I have it.
1∫t Ped. Will it be any ∫ati∫faction to you to be killed?
Bob. No.
1∫t Ped. Or to kill your adver∫ary?
Bob. Yes.

1∫t Ped. Malignant ∫pirit! By being ∫econd I may prevent extremities. (A∫ide.) Well, Sir, if you de∫ire it, though I do not con∫ider you as having any claim upon me more than another, I will accompany you, and ∫ee the matter adju∫ted. Where is your antagoni∫t, and when and where do you meet?
Bob. Gone to look for a ∫econd --in the fields --directly. --Perhaps your companion will be ∫econd to the other?
2d Ped. If he de∫ires it, I will accompany him.
Bob. Well, that ∫hows ∫ome pluck. I'll go tell him, and get the pi∫tols, and we'll have it out directly.
[Exit.

2d Ped. Well, Ned, we mu∫t act the part which good ∫econds ∫hould always play, not urge, but compo∫e the differences of the principles. If I can judge rightly, this Hector, though he talks big, does not much reli∫h
the bu∫ine∫s. But he ∫eems to be a bully, and again∫t ∫uch we mu∫t ever be upon our guard.
chap.head: AIR.

line.i: What a mon∫ter is man! that he'd rather revenge,
Than be great, though he's meek, and forgive;
His heart from his friend, for one word he'll e∫trange,
And forbid him to friend∫hip to live.

chap.p: Fir∫t Ped.

line.i: Revenge is a dæmon, the mi∫∫ive of hell;
But Forgivene∫s, an Angel from heaven,
Teaches be∫t how mankind may in hapine∫s dwell,
And forgive, as we would be forgiven.

chap.p: Both.

line.i: Then come, thou mild Angel, by fortitude arm'd,
And re∫i∫t the proud claims of thy foe,
And while at the pow'r of thy might he's alarm'd,
Hurl him down to his region below.

chap.p: [Exeunt.

chap.title: The Lakers ACT 3 SCENE II
chap.head: SCENE II.
chap.p: Enter Lydia.
Lydia. My fate, I hope, is now drawing towards a cri∫is. Sir Charles will a∫∫ert his cau∫e and my own, and relieve me from the irk∫ome ∫ituation I am in with my aunt.
chap.head: AIR.

line.i: Though envy di∫tre∫∫es,
And pride oft oppre∫∫es,
And lays all our happine∫s wa∫te;
Yet powerful love
Ev'ry care will remove,
And on high rear his banner at la∫t.

chap.p: Enter Veronica.

Ver. Well Lydia, my dear, Sir Charles is obligingly gone with the botani∫t to look for the Geranium batrachoides
flore eleganter variegato; he has promi∫ed to get me two or three roots to put into pots, for me to take back for the garden at Diandria Hall. --A va∫tly agreeable man is that Sir Charles. I don't think you admire him ∫o much as you did. You were quite enraptured with him at Lanca∫ter, but now you ∫eem quite indifferent.
Lydia You accu∫ed me, Madam, of in∫en∫ibility towards the Sir Charles Portin∫cale, who brought us hither in his carriage.

Ver. A very plea∫ant and picture∫que ∫cheme was that of Sir Charles. Yes, I had a mind to humour it, to give it effect. How ea∫y, how polite, how enlightened is Sir Charles! how rich too in the language of botany! The ∫oul-expanding delight of an intercommunication of ∫entiments with Sir Charles, when put in contradi∫tinction with the ob∫curation of intellect in that prominently di∫agreeable man, that roturier, his ∫ervant, is like the ro∫a provincialis compared with the allium ro∫eum.

Lydia I have little reason to be partialto the gentleman, as he ∫eems to have no partiality to me. His attentions are directed at you, Madam. It remains with you, therefore, to encourage or oppo∫e them.

Ver. Upon my word! a little jealous or ∫o! Sir Charles has di∫cernment, Mi∫s; and, if he prefers an enlightened mind to one not yet emerged from primitive darkne∫s and prejudice, ∫urely he is to make his own election where he thinks proper.
Lydia. Certainly, Madam.

Ver. And if Sir Charles would die, were I to be cruel, a truly philanthropic heart will bid him live to love and happine∫s. Yes, you will, before very long, be niece to Lady Beccabunga Portin∫cale; when the new plant the botani∫t has found will be called the Portin∫calia.
Lydia. If it is Sir Charles's and your wi∫h, I have neither a right nor a cau∫e to wi∫h it otherwi∫e.
Ver. Va∫tly obliging indeed! But I have been ∫o pre∫umptuous as ab∫olutely to con∫ent to the hymeneal union, without previou∫ly a∫king your permi∫∫ion.
Lydia. You are engaged, Madam?
Ver. Beyond the po∫∫ibility of retreating, but with the con∫ent of Sir Charles.
Lydia. I had no right to expect it; but perhaps, Madam, it might had been better had you con∫ulted me.

Ver. A∫toni∫hing impertinence! Yes, Mi∫s, and you may, if you like it, for I give you my free leave, go and marry his ∫ervant; or, perhaps, I may give you leave to marry the botani∫t. Yes, you may marry him.
Lydia. I thank you, Madam, for your goodne∫s.
Enter Anna.
Anna. O dear, Madam, I mu∫t beg your interpo∫ance: there is going to be ∫uch a confu∫ion of blood yonder.
Ver. Blood! Where?
Anna. At the foot of Skiddaw.
Ver. They could not have cho∫en a more picture∫que ∫ituation. But who is it?
Anna. My young ma∫ter.
Ver. Bob! A ∫illy blockhead! What bu∫ine∫s has he to be fighting? However, I'll introduce him in the foreground of a ∫ketch by way of a memorandum.
Lydia. Dear me, Madam, let us go: our pre∫ence, the pre∫ence of women, will prevent their proceeding to extremities.
Ver. Interfere in a duel! It would ab∫olutely cla∫s us among∫t the arums: we ∫hould be ara maculata.

Lydia. Con∫ider, Madam, that by refu∫ing our interference, where our pre∫ence might prevent a duel, we become parties in it, and ∫hall have to reproach ourselves with any accident which may happen to either my cou∫in Robert or his antagoni∫t.

Ver. Methinks, Mi∫s, you are a little too much gifted with verbiage. Be∫ides, were I to honour their combat with my pre∫ence, it would be, like one of the dam∫els of former times, to honour the conqueror with my gracious ∫miles.
Lydia. How do you know but his antagoni∫t may be Sir Charles Portin∫cale?
Ver. Bob dare as ∫oon fight Tippoo Saib.
Anna. It is, it is Sir Charles Portin∫cale.
Lydia. Heavens! Sir Charles! Perhaps it is only -- but the uncertainty is dreadful. (A∫ide.) O let us ha∫te this in∫tant.

Ver. How, Sir Charles! Lead me to the place. Oh, that I were papilionaceous. I run to his protection, and
let the fate-fraught tube di∫charge its leaden death into my brea∫t before it lodges in his manly heart.
chap.note: Flowers are called papilionaceous who∫e petals are like the wings of a butterfly.
chap.p: Anna. But hadn't you better take a con∫table? --
Ver. Vulgar expedient! No! I will be the mediator, the protector, and the deliverer: I perceive my love is growing acumenate:

line.i: Arm'd in my virgin innocence I fly,
My noble lover to protect or die.

chap.p: [Exeunt.

chap.title: The Lakes ACT 3 SCENE III.
chap.head: SCENE III.
chap.p: Speed. I have counterfeited love till I have almo∫t per∫uaded my∫elf into a real pa∫∫ion for this woman, and now I dread the di∫covery, le∫t it ∫hould ∫eparate me from her for ever. But, ∫uppo∫e ∫he ∫hould like me, and even con∫ent to marry me, would I have her? She is rich, ∫he is good tempered: two qualities that will certainly promote happine∫s in the married ∫tate. She does not want ∫en∫e; but then ∫he mi∫applies it. But it is perhaps for want of having it better directed, and the cares of a family may divert her attention another way. Then ∫he is a botani∫t, and deeply ver∫ed in the my∫teries of the loves of the plants; and ∫he, who is bawd to a blo∫∫om, may not be very nice in the intercour∫e of her own ∫pecies. I mu∫t have done with reflection, for the more I think the more I am bewildered.
chap.head: AIR.

line.i: Like the fal∫e light, that o'er the moor
The 'nighted traveller beguiles,
Woman exerts her artful power
To lure you with her wanton ∫miles.
A ray of hope fir∫t faintly gleams,
To cheer you on the lonely way,
And leads you on in airy dreams,
At la∫t your foot∫teps to betray.
You follow fa∫t through bu∫h and brake,
And force with pain the tangled brier,
In hopes at la∫t, for her dear ∫ake,
To gain the heaven you de∫ire.
But ah! at once in air di∫pers'd,
The fal∫e and fickle beauty turns;
And he, each ray of comfort lo∫t,
His haple∫s fate de∫pairing mourns.

chap.head: Enter Sir Charles Portin∫cale.
chap.p: Sir Charles. Speedwell, look yonder. Is not that Veronica's nephew coming this way, with a main in ∫ailor's jacket; and a little behind, Sample, with another in the ∫ame dre∫s?
Speed. As ∫ure as a gun it is, Sir, and they've got pi∫tols with them. Perhaps they are coming hither to fight a duel.
Sir Charles. Let us ∫tep a∫ide and observe them. (They retire.)
chap.head: Enter Bob Kiddy and Fir∫t Pede∫trian.
chap.p: Bob. No, I won't hear of an apology. I'll make him fight me.

1∫t Ped. Since you are determined, Sir, recollect that, as chance may equally go again∫t you, as in your favour, whether there is any thing you wi∫h to ∫ay, or any affairs you wi∫h to be ∫ettled, ∫hould you fall.
Bob. Should I fall! No.
1∫t Ped. If you ∫peak, Sir, from a con∫ciou∫ne∫s of being prepared for the wor∫t, happy is it for you. But the busine∫s you are upon, I fear, precludes any ∫uch favourable interpretation.
Bob. Why you don't mean to in∫ult me, do you? for, if you do, here's a brace of pi∫tols, and ∫tand your ground.
1∫t Ped. Why you would not fight your ∫econd, Sir, would you? The friend who ri∫ks his life for yours!
Bob. If you ri∫k it one way, why not another? But I won't put up with any ∫uch words.
1∫t Ped. Then, Sir, you mu∫t ∫wallow them down.
chap.head: Enter Sample and Second Pede∫trian.
chap.p: Sample. There he is, ∫peak to him.
2d Ped. I would fain, Sir, terminate this affair amicably, if it be po∫∫ible.
Bob. But it's impo∫∫ible.
2d Ped. Then I beg to ∫peak a word a∫ide with your ∫econd.
Bob. Come, come, no collu∫ion.
Sample. I ∫ee they won't let us fight. (The Pede∫trians walk a∫ide, Bob and Sample look at each other.)
Bob. Why you don't think I'll let you fight with tho∫e great hor∫e-pi∫tols, do you?
Sample. I thought I ∫hould frighten him. (A∫ide.)
Bob. Here, I've got two pair; you ∫hall take a pair of mine: here.
Sample. No, I won't. How do I know but you've loaded 'em with ∫lugs.
Bob. I believe you've done that your∫elf, by ∫u∫pecting me. (Pede∫trians come forward.)
1∫t Ped. If there is any difference re∫pecting the weapons, it is our bu∫ine∫s to adju∫t it.
Bob. No. Only I won't let him fire with tho∫e hor∫e pi∫tols. We mu∫t both have the ∫ame ∫ort; and ∫o he ∫hall take a pair of mine. I've got two pair. --Here.
2d Ped. But this gentleman ∫eems to ∫u∫pect they may not be fairly loaded. Let me ∫ee.
Bob. No, you ∫ha'n't. I believe his are not. Let me ∫ee them.
Sample. No, you ∫ha'n't.
1∫t Ped. I have a right to in∫i∫t in behalf of my principal.
2d Ped. And I of mine.
1∫t Ped. Give me your pi∫tols, Sir.
Sample. There. Oh, dear!
1∫t Ped. Why, there is no ball in either of them.
Sample. No, I thought I would not ∫hoot him: I only wanted to frighten him.
2d Ped. And now give me yours, if you plea∫e, Sir. (Bob gives one pair) --Come, gentlemen, I ∫ee neither of you bore the other any ill-will, for the∫e have no ball neither.
Sample. Well, that's very good natured of you. --Come, let's ∫hake hands.
Bob. With all my heart.
2d Ped. Stop, Sir. Ju∫t for the ∫ati∫faction of all the parties, let us examine the other pair.
Bob. No, they are ju∫t the ∫ame.

1∫t Ped. Nay, Sir, if you he∫itate, we mu∫t in∫i∫t upon it. (Takes them from him.)-- Loaded! The∫e are what you would have retained your∫elf, and the unloaded you would have forced upon your antagoni∫t. Infamous, treacherous murderer!
Bob. Why, 'twas the only way of fighting to my own ∫ati∫faction: --but I'm off.
2d Ped. Not ∫o ∫oon, Sir. This mu∫t not ∫top here.
Ver. (Without) Bob! Bob! Bob! If you fire, I will di∫inherit you. O Sir Chalres --
chap.head: Enters with Lydia and Anna.
chap.p: -- What, Bob and Speedwell! And has my inten∫e ∫olicitude been about my booby of a nephew and this odious bourgeois of a ∫ervant> Provoking! --there, you may fight it out. (Looking about her.) A mo∫t delightful ∫pot! The road hither was enchanting; passing through bowery lanes, luxuriant with beech, birch, mountain-a∫h, and holly. --That ravine is extremely picture∫que --that hill, covered with heath, turf, and brow∫ing ∫heep --the road ∫erpenting under that gnarled oak, with its tinty foliage --tho∫e beautiful boles, and that delicious di∫tant dippy-dell --
chap.head: Sir Charles and Speedwell come forward.
chap.p: O my dear Sir Charles! I have had ∫uch multifarious palpitations on your account. (To Speedwell.)
Lydia. I was anxious, Sir Charles, for your ∫afety: though I tru∫ted it was not you who was involved in the duel. (To Sir Charles.)
Anna. I am all of a trimble, and all on your account, Sir Charles. (To Sample.)
Bob. How do you do, Sir Charles? Are you pretty hearty? (To Sir Charles.)
Ver. Hey! how is this! Sir Charles! Sir Charles! Sir Charles!
Sir Charles. Sir, I have witne∫∫ed your infamous conduct, and di∫claim your acquaintance.
Ver. Why, what has he been doing?
Sir Charles. Was about to fire at his adver∫ary with balls, when he had given him pi∫tols with only powder in them.

Ver. A poltroon! How unlike the picture∫que virtues
of the ancients! when they met upon equal terms, ∫hook hands, and fought for honour and renown.
Speed. This comes, Sir, of "∫eeking the bubble reputation at the pi∫tol's mouth."
Sir Charles. Bubble, indeed! for it is blown upon, and bur∫t in air.
Ver. Sir Charles, as a military man, tell me what is to be done: for this ∫tory will get abroad, and I mu∫t give a full and per∫picacious account of it in my tour.
Speed. It is not for me to ∫peak in this in∫tance. I refer you to that gentleman.
Ver. That gentleman!
Sir Charles. If it were not for the pre∫ence of the∫e ladies, I should give you the cha∫ti∫ement due to a coward.

Ver. I beg that may be no objection. Be∫ides, by being witne∫s to it, I can give a more authenticated enarration, and more fully explain the chain of cau∫e and effect. Oh, Bob! Bob! He ought to be made to pa∫s sub jugum.
Sir Charles. Have you nothing to ∫ay for your∫elf, Sir?
Bob. No: I am ∫piflicated!
Sir Charles. Withdraw. Your own de∫picable cowardice, and the pre∫ence of the∫e ladies, alone prevent me from giving you the caning you merit.
Bob. I am much obliged to the ladies and my∫elf.
Ver. Bob, you don't enter my Sociable again.
Sample. No; he's not a ∫ociable man.
Bob. I've no re∫ource left but to turn tail upon the world, declaim against its vices, and ∫et up my∫elf as a pattern of every thing that's great and good.
[Exit.
Ver. Pray, Mr. Speedwell, how came you engaged in a duel with my nephew? Was it a duel prepen∫ed, or a fortuitous colli∫ion?

Sir Charles. Matters, Madam, are too much involved at this moment to be but partially adju∫ted. That gentleman's name is not Speedwell, nor is he a ∫ervant. He is a TRAVELLER, with whom I by chance changed cloathes, and who, having his own pur∫uits interrupted, by my having his articles of trade, a∫∫umed the name and title of Sir Charles Portin∫cale, thinking therewith to make his fortune.
Ver. What! I have been made love to by a bagman? --What a heterogeneous impre∫∫ion!
Anna. (A∫ide.) Then this wretch is no better than a ∫arvant.

Sir Charles. I am the real Sir Charles Portin∫cale, who, under∫tanding you always in∫i∫ted upon your niece re∫igning her claims with any admirer to you, acquie∫ced in his ∫cheme, and pa∫∫ed my∫elf upon you as the guide and botani∫t, to e∫cape your attacks, and have an opportunity of farthering my intentions with your niece. But, Mr. Sample, failing to per∫onate the character, I made him my ∫ervant upon you as my∫elf. Your niece has kindly conde∫cended to be mine; and, having an opportunity of declaring my∫elf, I now claim your forgivene∫s and con∫ent.
Ver. Impo∫∫ible!
Sample. Now the whole truth's out.
Speed. It is all very true.
Ver. Yes, Mr. Botani∫t, this is a cryptogamy, which I have not ∫een before, and had no idea of. Sir, you have not my con∫ent, and Lydia will never have one farthing of mine.
Sir Charles. My Lydia is her∫elf a trea∫ure of which no fortune can enhance the value. A few months will make her her own mi∫tre∫s; and we need not then be beholden to your con∫ent for our union.
Ver. Then my con∫ent is held to be merely ad∫cititious. But, Sir, there are exacerbations of the mind which--
Speed. I mu∫t again appeal to your amiable forgiving kinde∫s for this ∫econd deceit practi∫ed again∫t you. But perhaps your Lady∫hip was not deceived in this in∫tance.
Ver. Not a particle more than I was the fir∫t time.
Speed. May I hope it was my∫elf, and not my a∫∫umed title, that gained a heart which monarchs might proudly ∫igh for?
Ver. No, Sir, your in∫iduous flame--
Speed. May I then be permitted to remind you of a bond, which lately, with ∫eductive ∫impers, you were plea∫ed to force upon me?
Ver. Something extremely picture∫que in this man and his conduct; he has roughne∫s, ∫udden variation and intricacy; and if he were not a ∫ervant --(A∫ide.)

Speed. (Reads.) "I, Beccabunga Veronica, of Diandria Hall, do pledge m∫elf to marry the bearer, under forfeiture of all my e∫tate, my hortus ∫iccus, ∫ketches and writings. Given under my hand this day 21∫t day of--."
Ver. But you are not Sir Charles Portin∫cale. I ∫till abide by the forfeiture, if I refu∫e to marry Sir Charles Portin∫cale. Now what have you to ∫ay?
Speed. That the bond is made out to the bearer; and Sir Charles ∫hall exact it as he thinks be∫t. (Gives it Sir Charles.)
Sir Charles. My Lydia ∫hall di∫po∫e of it at her plea∫ure.
Lydia. I have no wi∫h to enforce the penalty. It is yours, Madam. (Gives it to Veronica.)
Ver. Quite a capriccio, I declare. And ∫o, Sir Charles, you ab∫olutely refu∫e me?
Sir Charles. I cannot accept you my∫elf, and I dare not recommend you to my ∫hadow.

Ver. I fear I ∫hall never get another offer half ∫o good, and I'm determined not "to wither on the virgin thorn." (A∫ide.) He's a va∫tly clever man, he's a botani∫t, he's picture∫que --I'll throw a Gilpin tint over him. (Looks through gla∫s.) Yes, he's gorgeou∫ly glowing. I mu∫t not view him with the other lights, for a hu∫band ∫hould not be either glaringly gloomy, or frigidly frozen; nor ∫hould I like to be haunted by a blue devil. --Then he's a ∫ervant -- but Lord Level married his daughter to a ∫ervant. I think the incident would be picture∫que; and it would be perfectly botanic for Veronica and Speedwell to marry.
Sir Charles. I will an∫wer for his honour, and ∫hall be happy to own him as a relation. I have proved the confidence I place in him, by a∫∫igning him the ta∫k of being my repre∫entative.

Ver. But ∫hall not I get laugh --No, a woman in my ∫ituation may act as ∫he plea∫es. We authore∫∫es are privileged people. But how much will my condition be apejorated. Pray, are you really a botani∫t? Is it your ∫pecific character? or was your botanic knowledge merely a∫∫umptuous?
Speed. What little knowledge I di∫played was really my own, and I hope to better it under your in∫tructions.
Ver. A very hopeful ∫cholar, truly!
Speed. May I then hope you will marry me?
Ver. Marry will I! We will be connate like the twin flowers on the ∫ame peduncle, and I tru∫t our love will be ∫empervirent and perennial. But Mr. --What's your name?
Sample. Sample, Mi∫s.
Ver. You are an exce∫∫ively bad practioner of the mimetic art, you have no artificiality; but as we all seem to be Dichotamous, I ∫uppo∫e you will marry my maid and amanuen∫is, Anna Katharina?
Sample. Who caught a mou∫e, Mi∫s?
Speed. I wonder ∫he has not ∫ometime ∫melt a rat.
Sample. Why, I ∫hould like her well enough, and, if ∫he'll have a ∫ide in my gig, I'll drive her home, and we'll ∫et up a ∫hop for our∫elves.
Anna. Yes, but I'd rather you'd been a baronet.
Sir Charles. But where are the two gentlemen who came as ∫econds to you and your adver∫ary?
1∫t Ped. Here, Sir. We but undertook the bu∫ine∫s to prevent any mi∫chief from en∫uing. We have ∫ucceeded and are ∫ati∫fied.
Sir Charles. May I reque∫t to know your names and conditions? Your words do not accord with your outward appearance.
1∫t Ped. We tru∫t, Sir, that we are gentlemen, though thus habited, and taking our tour on foot to gain a knowledge of our country and of mankind.

Ver. How fortunate! Pede∫trians! How picture∫que too their appearance --Another incident for my tour. I beg, Gentlemen, we may be better acquainted. I have often heard of the many who travel in this rational way, but was never before ∫o fortunate as to be acquainted with any. Let me entreat you to be aggregated into our party at the inn; and, if I may be ∫o bold as to entreat a ∫light account of your hi∫tory, to in∫ert in my tour, I ∫hall be particularly obligated to you. -- I ∫carce know, Sir Charles, in what manner we are to be cla∫∫ed; but as we are ∫o many flo∫cules compo∫ing one compound flos, I will pronounce us ∫yngenecious, of the order polygamia aqualis, except the Pede∫trians, who ∫eem to be as a modadelphia

Sir Charles. All di∫gui∫e being thus thrown off, however our follies may be laughed at, I tru∫t that the adventures of the LAKERS at Ke∫wick will afford an innocent amu∫ement to tho∫e who become acquainted with them, and that none of us will have any cau∫e to lament their denouement.
chap.head: FINALE.
chap.p: Sir Charles.

line.i: Happy days are now before us;
Let us rai∫e the tuneful ∫train,
Join the full and lively chorus,
Antidote to care and pain.

chap.p: Lydia.

line.i: Though the days we've pa∫t were grievous,
Yet, when pre∫ent joy appears,
Hope ∫till whi∫pers to relieve us,
And the di∫tant pro∫pect cheers.

chap.p: Chorus. Happy days, etc.
Speedwell.

stanza.line: Though Veronica's Diandria,

line.i: This her cla∫s will ∫he for∫wear;
Will ∫he love a ∫ingle wanderer,
Con∫tant to an only dear?

chap.p: Veronica.

stanza.line: Hitherto, like CAPRIFICA,
"Single wretchedne∫s" I've known;

line.i: My botanic love I like here,
And my man I'll love alone.

chap.p: Chorus. Happy days, etc.
Sample.

line.i: Will my bounty bale of beauty
All her ∫trange vagaries drop,
And with me, in bounden duty,
Wait upon our retail shop?

chap.p: Anna.

line.i: I had lik'd a man of larning,
If with ∫uch I could have wed,
But an half-load I've di∫caring
To prefer to lack of bread.

chap.p: Chorus. Happy days, etc.
Fir∫t Pede∫trian.

line.i: We will ∫till, our aim pur∫uing,
For improvement travel on,
Men and manners ∫till be viewing,
Making all we ∫ee our own.

chap.p: Second Pede∫trian.

line.i: We not envy power nor riches:
We have plea∫ure, we have health;
And experience fully teaches
The∫e alone are ∫olid wealth.

chap.p: Chorus

line.i: Happy days are now before us;
Let us rai∫e the tuneful ∫train,
Join the full and lively chorus,
Antidote to care and pain.

chap.head: THE END.
